Student%20Life.Author: Recent Alumnus

Student%20Life.Review: Don't Bother – From a female perspective, the guys at U of C are extremely cocky for being not very good looking. There are a couple attractive ones, but generally their personalities outweigh anything positive about their appearance. There are certainly exceptions, and as friends the guys are typically hilarious. Additionally, I'm sure the guys would also say terrible things about the girls. I don't see a lot of dating; plenty of hooking up. There's a lot of awkwardness and it's amusing.
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: No one is overweight. Almost all students are very in shape for their body types. There is a great divide in types of people. There are the more studious ones who tend to not be very social, and then there are others who study hard but their life doesn't revolve around grades and they have more of a social life
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: Extremely Diverse – In all aspects of the word.  Every individual is extraordinarily unique in their own way.
Student%20Life.Author: College Senior

Student%20Life.Review: Wild Wild West – Underage drinking is rampant and nobody cares as long as you make sure it remains your business. The fraternities that throw parties get shut down but rarely do students get in trouble. Housing is very lax in terms of the extent to which they will prevent vandalism and noise during quiet hours, which is why UChicago only gets an A-. Sometimes the lack of strictness can be a really annoying problem.
Student%20Life.Author: College Junior

Student%20Life.Review: Greek Perspective – I am Greek and I would hate the school if I wasn't. Greeks are judged a lot though by non-Greeks and Greek students are definitely in the minority. Most athletes are part of the Greek life. I think the whole social scene of our school comes from Greek life. Without the fraternities I don't know where people would party.  There is a lot of rivalry between Greek organizations as well, but only Greek students care about it. A lot of non-Greeks do not  know that Greek like even exists or do not care.
Student%20Life.Author: College Senior

Student%20Life.Review: As a varsity athlete, it is disappointing to hear that some students don't even know we have varsity teams. More support at events, besides just the athletes who can empathize, would be great.
Student%20Life.Author: College Senior

Student%20Life.Review: Relatively Loose. Academic honesty is very emphasized at our school. However, it seems that kids find their ways around it regardless... Our school has virtually no limits on social lives. Drinking in the dormitories are permitted as long as they are not publicly disturbing. Underage drinking is very prominent as well. Hence, social lives are virtually limitless. They say University of Chicago is where the fun goes to die but in my opinion this is not much because of the school's policies but more because of the students' personalities themselves.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Student%20Life.Review: Greek life is smaller here compared to other schools, but we're definitely still as involved and spirited as other universities. And of course, I absolutely love the community.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: If You Look for It, You'll Find It. Pretty much any demographic you can imagine is included on campus, though some more prevalent then others. International students also make up a huge portion of the student body.
Student%20Life.Author: College Freshman

Student%20Life.Review: At the Lower Division – Although sports were big time at the university,Chicago places no emphasis on sports now.The University of Chicago once belonged to the Big Ten and had the first Heisman Trophy winner. Now they play in a lower division.
Student%20Life.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Lots of great options within and outside of majors.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Academics are rigorous, and the workload can sometimes be overwhelming.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: As an art major it was a little difficult because there aren't nearly as many resources, classes, or professors available. If you're into math and science, this is the place for you.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Really unparalleled. Sometimes way too hard but amazing education.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: I really enjoy the structure of the curriculum here at the University of Chicago. I think the quarter system is great for the most part, and I like the core and the variety of classes offered.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: It's a college, which means the breadth of majors is not the same at a major university; however, the programs themselves are fantastic and teach the students a lot.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Very easy to navigate course registration process, a really large diversity of study options, and the professors are all very smart.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Difficult, intense, amazing, and fulfilling. Some of the brightest students in the world come here, and intellectual life on campus is some of the best intellectual life you'll ever get anywhere.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: It's very easy to switch majors, since there is only one undergraduate division, the college. Furthermore, the undergraduate curriculum starts off with the core, so there's a lot of time for people to decide what they want to major in. The econ majors can be kind of annoying at times.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: You are a student of the university as a whole, not some annoying arbitrary sub-college, so you can take pretty much any classes you want to, using the same hassle-free form. Many, many high-paid internships.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Chicago is unsurpassed academically, check the sub-score described as "academics" in any college ranking you prefer.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Easily got internship with alumnus, then large NY investment bank.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Math majors rule the roost, everyone knows they are smart and treats them nicely.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: No bureaucracy at all for getting into classes. I got into 99% of classes I wanted to, the first time. You can take classes painlessly in any department, graduate school, etc.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Most students do internships after first year..
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Pretty intense academically, pretty competitive, can be a bit stressful if you don't stay on top of everything.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: There are a lot of opportunities for internships
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: It is easy to pick a major and you can get into any program you'd like
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: A lot of access to internships: I have interned at the governor's office and with Equality Illinois and they have both been very rewarding.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Economics major is very good. Program is strong and the professors are excellent. Some econ majors are a self-inflated but I think that might be the general student body.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: I have been a research assistant in a psychology lab for a few quarters now and I have learned a lot about research.  In addition, finding an internship is not too difficult.  The university has programs where researchers, businessmen, etc. come to UChicago to look for students who want an internship.  In addition, just having an uchicago email address often gets potential employers, researchers, etc to respond quicker.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: They tailor degrees for the careers of the student's choice.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Tons of internship/research opportunities, great classes, great professors, great students.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The process of declaration is very easy and informal, can happen late in the game, can easily be changed/switched, etc. The major requirements make sense, are often very modular and flexible, and you can request for certain classes to count towards your major (though it might take awhile for the request to be processed, it very often is accepted). There of course is a wide selection of majors, and double majoring even in completely unrelated subjects is quite doable. In fact, it is (in theory) possible to get a quadruple major without taking extra classes.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The history classes are all quite specific and focused, leading to a very deep and intricate understanding of key issues. The general survey courses are also quite good, though, and acquaint you with the most important figures and events and the trends in a meaningful, considerate way.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Even if you somehow get an apathetic or mediocre professor, the nature of the material you're confronted with and expected to grapple with will still be incredibly interesting, stimulating, rigorous, and challenging.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: It was very simple for me to apply for my major. All I needed to do was list Chemistry as my choice and it was given to me.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I have lots of people supporting me through this process.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: There's tons of support on campus for whatever your degree is.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Top-notch education. You suffer, but boy, do you learn. I wouldn't go anywhere else.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: The academics, while very challenging, make you entirely prepared for a career in whatever you're studying.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: There is a wide variety in math, science, and politics. Not much else
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I have studied with very good teacher. This is the best part.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: My major is in literature. I love my class. I have a chance to study world best literature here and discuss with others students.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: They have a website where they post lots of internships specifically for UChicago students, but to be honest I don't think I know anyone who's ever gotten one of those. I've had internships with my Senator on Capitol Hill and with a major healthcare company's government affairs division, but both of those I got on my own. UChicago on your resume only helps if there aren't 50 other UChicago kids applying for the same internship.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review:
I'm a political science/public policy double major.

Political science is fairly large, probably one of the largest. There's a decent (but not great) selection of poli sci courses offered each quarter, but the requirements are really easy to fulfill so it isn't like you need to take one each quarter if there aren't any you like. It's basically just any 12 poli sci classes you want (although I've heard rumblings they may be making stricter requirements for future years). The professors are generally quite good and the top of their field. I'd recommend classes with Lipson, Rosenberg, and Pape (he's kind of a vain, but he's really interesting) when they're offered. They started an Institute of Politics last year that brings in speakers pretty regularly, so that's a great resource if you're interested in politics. Theoretically they also help get poli sci internships, I haven't seen much evidence of that though. 

Public Policy is smaller (although growing, I think). It's like a more rigorous poli sci, and you can double count four of the classes for poli sci too, so it makes a very easy double major. You have to take specific classes in math, econ, and stats, as well as specific public policy courses, but the classes are generally pretty good.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: hard. hum and sosc are a breeze. anything real isnt
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: You apply to the College, not a specific program here. Definitely eliminates the stress of having to choose when you're only a high school senior.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: It's a world renown school therefore all of the academics are very highly esteemed.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Workload isn't all to bad, it's not nearly as bad as I assumed it would be. What's nice here is that they don't pressure you to pick your major until after your first year- your first year you take all core classes.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: I plan to get one, they are super helpful in getting full-time jobs.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Fantastic program for someone interested in paleontology-oriented biology. Great courses and faculty in that field. Also provides great opportunities to network and meet others before graduate school. A solid A.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: The University of Chicago is known for their academics and the school certainly delivers. The professors are some of the best in their fields- many of them have written the textbooks for the classes. The instructors are always willing to talk to students- mostly to discuss and debate ideas. The academics at Chicago are split into three pieces: 1/3 are the core requirements all students must take, 1/3 are the classes in a major and the final 1/3 are electives; electives can result in a second major, minor, or the exploration of another language or student interest. A love of learning is present at the school and academics certainly take center stage.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: My experience with staff of Social Service Department has been great. The college is ranked in the top 5 in the world.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Getting into Public Policy was really easy. You just choose sometime your second or third year after taking classes in the major. Then you just declare online and you have to write a B.A and take the corresponding classes.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: I am fairly sure I will major in math. The department has legendary professors who really care about students. I had no intention of being a math major before coming here but the theoretical approach here made it so much cooler that I really grew to love it. Do the REU program.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Probably the most learning I have ever accomplished in one year.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Uchicago is famous for its Academics environment which is rich and vibrant.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: I majored in History.  The unique feature is you must choose an area of history to focus on, like American, European, East Asian, etc.  Then usually you have the option of doing a senior research project.  The workload on top of the general curriculum is pretty substantial.  You will do a ton of reading.  The trick is picking your fights because there is simply no way for you to do all the reading at an appreciative level.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: The process was pretty easy.  With a history major, you just need to declare that is your major and take the required curriculum, but make sure you can fit it all into your schedule.  Other majors like Economics take much longer to fulfill and usually is best for those who declare much earlier.  Same for physics.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: If you think you want to be pre-med, go somewhere else. There's no encouragement at UChicago.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: I thought the University of Chicago's admissions process was unique and really helped me get to know the school.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: The workload is very heavy for chemistry majors.  However, the challenges offered in the courses are beneficial for understanding the theory. There are not many internships available.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: I'm in the humanities program for the classics and I knew going in I wouldn't be disappointed. I went to Chicago for its reputation of classes and professors. They are all extremely knowledgeable and helpful with advancement in the program. The classes are difficult but that only encourages me to study more.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: The university offers a wide variety of classes which is great and the curriculum is definitely rigorous which is what I expect. I want to be challenged in my education and I was not disappointed. The professors are personable and want to help you succeed.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Easy to Do – Picking a major is very easy and switching majors is even easier. UChicago has the CORE--certain classes every person must take, then choosing a major just depends on what you like and what classes you want to take!
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: I just started, so I can't provide a precise answer.  So far, yes I would do it again.  I hope by earning a masters I qualify for more jobs within University Administration.  I think you need a solid educational background if your career goals are to provide one.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review:
This program is mainly for working adults.  Class schedules are very convenient (nights and weekends).  Workload is heavy (reading mostly), curriculum is very broad as it is a Liberal Arts program.

The facilities are top rate, located across the Wrigley building in downtown Chicago.  As for job opps, this program is not exactly designed for immediate job results.  It is more personal growth that you can apply into your professional endeavors.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: I had to submit previous essays and write a 5 page paper on why I wanted to be admitted into the program.  I also had to provide 2 recommendations and my undergraduate transcripts.  I found the application process extremely easy.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review:
I am a double major in International Studies and Public Policy, so this review only applies to those two.

IS: An interesting major with a LOT of flexibility as it is interdisciplinary. Many classes in the humanities and social sciences will count toward your degree, and you get exposure to many fields. You also MUST study abroad during the course of the program, which is a valuable experience. The head of the department is also a great professor who really likes to talk to students and be involved. However, this major requires a lot of self-direction because of how loose it is, and many students don't acquire that skill. Administratively, it's quite unorganized and it can be a pain to find classes if you are not interested in either human rights or NGOs/development.

Public Policy: Another loosely organized major, though with more requirements than IS. Many classes in the social sciences and economics will count toward it. The major really helps you understand the workings behind real world policy decisions/institutions and gives you a more nuanced understanding of current events. The major includes a practicum where you practice research skills and policy writing. However, it can be an administrative nightmare as well because of the open-endedness of the major.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: We don't have many very specific majors, and no engineering, advertising, or graphic art, but we have broad fields (Visual Arts, Cinema & Media Studies, etc.) There are actually a lot of different majors and classes!
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Life of the mind flourishes. You will not find a better academic experience, assuming you put in the requisite effort.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: You will do more work than you thought possible, and love every minute of it.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: UChicago is known for their unusual supplement essays, but students need to have fun with it.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: As an international student (not US citizen) I have a hard time with finding an internship. However, I have many friends who have been more succesful in finding one.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The process of getting into my International studies major was pretty easy. I've just declared my major online and had a meeting with my student adviser and the department adviser. The hard part was getting into college itself.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: As an international studies and political science major, I beliave I will not have problem with finding a job. However, I would like to earn Master's degree first to ensure a better career options.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: I study International relations and political science at the University of Chicago. I really enjoy my majors. I'm not absolutely sure I want to double major. Nevertheless, as a sophomore I can study both at the moment, since the course load of the two overlaps. Plus International studies is a really open major.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The best of the best. A UChicago education is a solid education. Our core is fantastic and our teachers superb (and they teach undergraduates)!
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: There could be more majors relevant to present day life
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Hard but So Worth It – I love being pushed, and UChicago definitely pushes me. Excellent profs, students really help each other (not much competition since everyone eventually will probably need help in a class). But, despite our reputation, the workload is totally manageable, and the core is really exciting.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: You Get Out What You Put in – The professors at UChicago are a mixed bag. Some are amazing, some are not as amazing. Getting to know your professor, though, which is one of the integral parts of enjoying and engaging in a class is going to see the professors outside of class. Once I started, I got so much more out of my experience.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Just Take the Right Classes – Very easy process. You just have to take the right distribution of classes to satisfy the requirements of the major. This means you don't have to decide on your major until your second, third, or even fourth year.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Students Love School Here – Academics are a huge part of UChicago life. Students are super passionate about what they are studying, and professors encourage class discussion so that classes are not a lecture, but rather a conversation where everyone is encouraged to voice their ideas and opinions.  The philosophy behind education at the University of Chicago is one that teaches the student to think critically and learn how to analyze texts and approach problems from all different sorts of angles.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: Political Science – Our political science department has a varied group of big name professors like John Mearsheimer and Robert Pape, but also has some truly superb experts in their own right like Charles Lipson, Bernard Silberman, Nathan Tarcov, Ralph Lerner and many others.  There are both large and small classes, and they fit well into the context of broader Core learning.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: University of Chicago is an academic experience like no other. I give it an A+, although we do not give A+s here(just As, and those are difficult to come by). If you have a passion for knowledge, this is the place for you. The professors are well-known in their fields, and research opportunities abound.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Strong Environmental Program in an Urban Context – I'm an Environmental Studies major, and I have been extremely impressed with the program at UChicago.  I wouldn't have expected a school in a city like Chicago to have an excellent program oriented toward the environment, but it turns out that our urban location is in many ways a strength, and sets our program apart from that of other schools.  Our Environmental Studies major has a strong focus on policy, and the faculty and staff do an incredible job of keeping students in the loop with regards to professional opportunities in Chicago.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: The psychology program here is very research based. If you wish, there are many opportunities to get involved in as many psychology labs as you would like.  Most classes are taught by professors, or people who run their own labs. There is a SOSC class called "mind" that many psychology faculty members co-teach, and is a great opportunity to get an idea of who you might want to take classes with. All of the professors within the psychology department want to see you succeed, and will do pretty much anything to help you. Additionally, if you enjoy psychology but you are not interested in research, there is a joint degree program with the school of social work, where you can get a jump start on your clinical studies.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Computer Science – pretty damn awesome to be honest - the program is starting to grow a lot, programming aspect of CS is making a presence on campus with growing organizations like TechBrite. The professors are extremely laid back and approachable for the most part, and you easily forget some formalities around them. The theory classes are ridiculously strong, and the applied ones have been quite good. I suppose the only weakness is that the department is relatively smal, but it's easily overlooked
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The focus is very much on experimental psychology so you have to put in extra effort to find out about applied options.  Professors and program are excellent.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Core Curriculum Is Boring but Classes Are Still Interesting – The core curriculum is sometimes kind of lame because you're required to take some classes that you find boring but other than that its great! The workload is manageable is you're a hard worker.
Academics.Author: College Freshman

Academics.Review: Most Popular Major: Economics – The University of Chicago has one of the most prestigious econ programs in the world, and everyone is always fairly impressed by it.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Tough, but Doable – If you're used to getting straight A's and being the "smart kid" in all of your classes, this school can be an incredibly jarring experience - because EVERYONE was that kid!  But while the school is tough (and sometimes, it seems, unreasonably so), it's very doable.  The Computer Science department is very hit-or-miss teacher-wise, but you can definitely craft a curriculum with tons of hands on experience, and all of the professors I've had are, if not the best teachers, very excited to assist students.  One thing you'll hear about the Computer Science department at this school is that you will only get theoretical experience...but this is folly.  I've crafted Operating Systems, networking applications, video games and more - the education you'll get here is perfectly fine.  (You will have to get some alternate programming language experience outside of the classroom, however).
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: U of C Physics – You don't have to apply into any major, if you get in the school you can be any major you want.  It's very hard, but at the top of it's field.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Rigorous but Worth It – The U of C is tough, there's no getting around it.  There are times when you are buried in work with no way out.  However, you learn in a way that is really unique and actually makes you smart.  You don't really have to learn useless facts here.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Great Curriculum – I love the core first off. And I love my major. The workload is manageable, there is a lot of hands on experience available, and the teachers are: intelligent, accessible, and willing to help you find your way.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Great Program – I am a public policy major and the program seems amazing! They are quite flexible and offer many ways to complete different requirements. The curriculum is very interested and the professors are at the top of their fields.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Intellectual Experience – Exciting,intellectual environment,and opportunities are around every corner all it need is an explorer to discover it. This university provides its student to the best of thier capabilities and more. Its really up to the students to seek and claim those chances inorder to recieve a better education. As well as a learning experience worth the money they are going to invest in this university.At times its bewildering for transfer students for a ease process of entering this university.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Big Name Profs – The psychology department has some really impressive professors who are surprisingly accessible and are willing to take even the first and second years for various experiments. Also, Uchicago has a massive excess of grad students who teach/assist in the undergrad classes so there's usually a ratio of 1-5 for the number of qualified instructors per student.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: A Great Challenge – I came to the University of Chicago because it had a strong academic reputation, and it certainly has lived up to standards. Students here are very smart and work extremely hard, which means that if you don't put 110% into a class, you will not get an A. There is so much to learn! And pretty much everyone is excited to do it.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: I'll Show You the Life of the Mind! UChicago academics are second to none. I've never had such amazing conversations; everyone is so fascinated by their area of study and so willing to share what they've learned. And, if you make a Marx joke, everyone will get it. Everyone.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: UNRIVALED Core, Professors, and Academic Philosophy – I could not possibly be happier with my academic experiences thus far at the University of Chicago.  The Core may seem daunting at first, but there really is no better way to get the true liberal arts "big picture."  There are tons of course options within each Core requirement.  Yes, there have been a few professors that I meshed with better than others, but no matter what, they have all been extremely supportive and willing to help/discuss things further outside of class, and they are all clearly at the top of their respective fields.  What I love most about UChicago is its overall academic philosophy--the idea that learning should be for the sake of learning.  Of course we're all still fairly career-oriented, but we know that the best way to get there is to truly get a comprehensive education and fully understand that which we are studying.  For example, in the long run, doesn't it make more sense to be an Economics major [especially at U of C] than to just be a "Marketing" major at some other school [which is fairly limiting]?
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Flexible With Knowledgable Professors – There are a lot of things you can do with history at UChicago: there are a lot of specialties, and the professors really know what they're talking about. I haven't taken a "bad" history class here, and many good ones.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Difficult but Rewarding – Chicago is known for its rigorous academic environment and emphasis on theory rather than practically. Professors are generally excellent, the Core can be challenging and enlightening (or easy and dull depending on the classes you choose), the workload is generally three or four classes per quarter and typically quite difficult, and there are many libraries and study areas packed with students during peak times.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: You'll Get a Lot of These. We are quite famous for grade deflation, so don't let that wear you out. Many professors will be tough graders and full of questions, but working hard and finishing the assignments will give you at least a B. Hard sciences and math tend to have a wider distribution of graders, but the departments understand this. The work load is manageable, and it is up to you to figure out which things matter more. You will be challenged and love it.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Tough Luck – U of C is academically tough. Do not come here if you do not want to be challenged.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review:
Helpful, Intelligent Professors and Small, Theoretical Classes – The Sociology Department at the U of C is excellent. Though I've had a few classes that are 30 or 35 kids (this is really large for U of C), classes are interesting and discussion is intelligent. Generally the professors lead part-lecture part-discussion classes. Sociology of the U of C is theoretical; we read the great classic writers and more modern writers. Though you do need to take statistics, there is not a huge emphasis on it in your classes (at least not yet for me). Some think this is a good thing, some think it is bad (I once talked to a professor about this- he was on the second side). I happen to like it. The professors are also, in my experience, incredibly willing to talk and meet with you outside of class.
The workload isn't horrible, and since our program is so great, there are plenty of job and intership opportunities after and in college.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: A number of the professors are overrated and are more concerned with their research than actually educating the students. Many of them have very poor English so it is hard to understand them.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Challenging but Gratifying – The Economics curriculum at U of C is more heavily mathematics-based than the curricula at other universities (which are more theory-based). The core sequence is typically taught by grad students, but they really know their stuff and are willing to help. The email internship/job listhosts are also very helpful for job searches. The program is very well-respected, and the U of C brand name generally helps a resume stand out.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: You have to work extremely hard no matter what you study, no matter who your professor is, and no matter how smart you were in high school.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Summer Opportunities Can Be a Struggle – I'm a Biology major/pre-med at the College, and I have found that although many of the profs are conducting research in their own labs, summer opportunities, especially paid ones, are hard to come by. Once you have found a connection, though, the networking possibilities that come out of it are excellent. As far as purely educational aspects, the workload is quite overwhelming, but you come out of it feeling like you have gained some real knowledge.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: Core Cirriculum – The Core can be a pain in the butt but completing it gives you a well rounded education and helps you learn problem solving skills.
Academics.Author: College Senior

Academics.Review: I was almost a straight A student in high school, graduating as part of the top 5% of scholars in California. My interest in medicine prompted me to choose biology as my major with hopes of going to medical school. However, the grade deflation at this school is so harsh that many say that it is unrealistic for pre-medical students from the University of Chicago to go to medical students matching their skills. That is to say, many people on the pre-medical track at my school would rather now transfer to a different perhaps less prestigious school in exchange for classes with lower workloads and less grade deflation. Moreover, the workload is overwhelming in that over 50 kids dropped out of my general chemistry class. Overall, I would never recommend our school to pre-medical students. If i had to choose any benefits I got from this school on my track to medical school though, it would definitely be the vast number of research opportunities so easily obtainable; not to mention that often times the research opportunity you would get at this school will most likely be under a renown professor.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review:
The University of Chicago is a top notch academic institution.  They fly and house some of the top researcher in any field in to teach even undergraduate course.  I have had nationally known professors teach me in Chemistry courses (Yamamoto) and Comparative Human Development course (Margaret Spencer).  The curriculum can be abstract at times.  It is a research oriented institutions so factual knowledge is not fostered much.  
This is the place for inquisitive and exploratory minds.  The coursework and workload can be difficult and rigorous, but no matter what type of education you are seeking you are sure to get the best research oriented education post secondary education has to offer.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: My Major Is Very Supreme. There is a lot of reading as well as writing involve.Critical thinking is the order of the day.
Academics.Author: College Junior

Academics.Review: The academics and professors at the University of Chicago are top flight.Academics are very rigorous and the professors are close to the students.All students participate in class discussions for it is mandatory in the core classes.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: Fantastic teachers, top-niche curriculum, heavy workload
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review:
Great Resources for Students Looking to Advance Their Studies – Chicago gives its students incredible freedom to pursue academic aspirations at a level that goes beyond just discussing the textbooks.  This university has serious street cred in many fields, such as sociology, archeology, chemistry, biology, astronomy, the humanities, and economics.  

One thing that a lot of students have in common with the faculty who teach them is that they like to delve into topics slightly off the beaten path.  Some students think, "Wouldn't it be great if I did ..."  If you make a good proposal, most likely you can do it here or with the college's blessing.  If you want to spend a summer at an NGO overseas, there's a college grant for that.  And if you want to discover lost species in the Gobi desert or observe older regions of the galaxy, this place can help you do that, too. Or maybe you know a bit about finance but you're interested specifically in art auctions, pricing what are priceless paintings.  These are all examples of neat things that people I've known have done while attending the U of C. The Core curriculum is important, but it's not as rigid as it might sound.  An important part of the "typical" Chicago education is the exploration of the not-so-typical.
  
There is a lot more to Chicago life than academics, of course.  The student community is fairly small and cozy, and activities hosted by one organization or another (even Greek parties) are generally open to everyone in the campus community. Although the courses stress academic criticism, people are considerate (especially in debate) and the students love games. The epic scavenger hunt that goes on every spring demonstrates that fun is alive and well.
Academics.Author: Recent Alumnus

Academics.Review: Definitely deserves its ranking as one of the top schools in the world!
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Academics.Review: The teachers here clearly know what they are doing, even if some of the intro level classes are taught by graduate students. The classes themselves can be very tough and challenging, it strives the students to do their best. Our core curriculum is set for the students to explore wide range of areas including humanities, social science, physical science, biological science, and music/art/drama. I think this is a great school to spend the 4 years in college.
Academics.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: One of the most beautiful college campuses I've ever seen
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Chicago is the greatest city in the world, no question about it.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Hyde Park is a nice neighborhood but UChicago's location is best because it's very easy to get to the heart of downtown or to the train.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The fact that the University is located close to the city is great! It means that there is always something to do off campus. However, this doesn't in any way diminish from the events going on on-campus. There is also usually something to do there as well. The local attitude seems to be generally positive, and, as mentioned before, there is a great variety of events available.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Campus quality id generally good. There are a wide range of facilities to serve most needs. I have found everything that I needed here.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Hyde park is a nice neighborhood and one that continues to develop. I would prefer to move out of it once I graduate but for right now, it's a nice place to go to school.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Campus is very beautiful - there are a lot of plants and beautiful things on campus. All the facilities and amenities are always very well maintained.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Hyde Park is an OK college town. we have a few things to do, but of course the city of chicago is there if students ever want more.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Very pretty old stone buildings, everything is pretty conveniently located.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: It's the best of both worlds: the University is in a pretty, quiet academic suburb, and you're 20 minutes away from the big city of Chicago itself.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review:
Downtown Chicago is great but getting there is a pain (public transortation).

Hyde Park is pretty quiet and not the safest neighborhood.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Hyde park is safe and feels somewhat college-y but there's not much to do in the neighborhood.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Hyde Park is pretty sleepy.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Chicago is a great city and there is always something interesting going on. It's worth just for the museums alone.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Parking can be hard during the week.  However, on and around campus there is free parking.  After 5pm on Friday until early Monday morning, the North Campus Parking Garage is free.  However, you do not need a car since there is public transportation, zip car, and of course the UChicago shuttles.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: This school is very unique.  First, we have one of the latest starts in the country (late sept/early oct) and end the latest (mid-june).  In addition, we have the world's largest scavenged hunt.  However, the housing system is particularly unique since it has a Harry Potter style of sorting people based upon common interests, which promotes house rivalries, especially ones in the same building.  For example, before Pierce was torn down, the houses had a tradition of competing in events to determine which was the best house.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: While I was in the dorms, the wireless internet speed was around 75 mbps.  Around campus, it is around this speed also, but can be spotty in some building.  Printing is available, but not cheap.  There was/is (not sure) a free printing service, but it was hacked into and all the user info was leaked (uchicago id/password and personal info).
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The university has a shuttle program that runs from 5pm to 3am daily.  In addition, they just added a day-time shuttle for students to get to class quicker.  Also, the CTA has two free buses for UChicago students.  On and around campus, there are many Zipcars that are affordable and often available.  About 10 minutes from campus, the Metra will take you to the Loop and back for $6 and the CTA has buses that take you to and from CTA trains and of course around Chicago.  Union station will also take you to Indiana (say you want to visit Notre Dame) or around Chicago.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There is not a ton to do in Hyde Park.  The university does not hold many events, so outside of the few bars in Hyde Park and frat parties, there is not much to do.  A quick taxi/bus/train ride will bring you to any upbeat neighborhood in Chicago, where bars and clubs are plentiful.  Hyde Park is a nice neighborhood that has a good attitude towards the students.  In addition, I find the food in Chicago to be lackluster, but it is often cheaper than where I came from.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It rains a lot and they don't call it the Windy City for nothing.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Chicago is one of the greatest cities in the US! There's plenty to do, see, etc.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: So it gets really cold and snows a lot, but it's doable. I actually found myself enjoying the cool spring and fall.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The long-running shuttles are fantastic, consistent, frequent, and cover all your possible options. They're also incredibly easy to understand. Everyone complains about the CTA, but it's actually relatively cheap, and if you ACTUALLY LOOK AT A MAP it's remarkably easy as well. Starting from your dorm, you'll seldom have to walk more than a total of 4 blocks to get to your destination anywhere in the city.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Personal computers are relatively important, especially if you don't live near the Reg. Stories about the network & connectivity vary wildly.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's a city, it can be dangerous if you don't use common sense, but it can also be nice because things are relatively accessible.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It varies. The 2013-2014 winter was  really brutal. We experienced a few polar vortexes and it was well  below zero pretty frequently. Apparently this was an exceptionally bad year, but it was pretty miserable. A lot of us from warmer climates adjusted better than expected, so it's definitely doable, but I would prefer to be somewhere where it was generally warmer.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I have my own computer, so I'm pretty oblivious to the availability of computers, but they do seem pretty prevalent around campus. You could probably manage without having your own.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are public buses that run throughout the day that can get you around campus which are free to students. There are school shuttles that run at night, which serve the same purpose. It's pretty reasonable to get downtown, there are a lot of buses and trains that pick up near campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I have my own computer so that makes it easier.  Wifi gets iffy during finals though
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: 7 miles from downtown Chicago, the university is in a fun (although not so safe) neighborhood
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: To be honest, I don't really use shuttles because I think its faster to walk most places.  To get downtown, I just take a cab, it's super easy.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review:
Everyone has their own computer, but you could probably get by without it.

The internet is pretty reliable
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are night time shuttles around campus that help
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Weather is definitely bad, and it has been a struggle, but I'm alive and fine.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Access to the city is available, and the area we are in is nice
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Downtown is about a 40 minute train ride, so many students stay in Hyde Park for most of the week. It is a nice community.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Recently the wireless network has been spotty and only will work sometimes.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It is very cold and snows a very often, but it didn't take long for me to adjust to the climate change.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Oh the things you'll learn and do while at uchicago.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The housing system means there is always someone, and they become family.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Just beware of the winter. But fall is absolutely fantastic, and the snow is beautiful.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Everyone has their own computer- just the way it is. We have fantastic wifi. Printing on campus is easy.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's frigid. It dips below 10 degrees Fahrenheit, and it feels worse with the windchill.
Campus.Author: Niche User

Campus.Review: Plenty of buses and trains can get you downtown. The shuttle system for getting around HP is good, but it doesn't start running until 5 pm. There are CTA buses that are free to students, as well, but their routes aren't as expansive as the shuttles. There's a new 53rd street express that runs weekdays and goes from campus to 53rd street. Overall it's fine.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: You don't want all of your off-campus activities to be in Hyde Park, but that doesn't mean you shouldn't get to know it. Go to the restaurants, see movies at Harper Theatre, visit the Museum of Science and Industry, have barbecues on the lakefront, volunteer in the community, and so forth.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There are free spots in less busy residential areas. Usually these are far from campus but Woodlawn often has open free spots. Street cleaning means you have to occasionally find a new spot so if you have a car, be aware of the cleaning schedule where you park.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The CTA (Chicago public transportation) is sometimes pricey but there are a lot of places you can go on it. The campus shuttle system is very easy to use especially with the TransLoc phone app, but some lines only run at night which is annoying.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The cold definitely changes my mood. Sometimes it's in a good way - that cozy hot-chocolate feel. But often it's just painful and inconvenient to go outside. I started liking the school a lot more when spring came around and I don't think that's a coincidence.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The campus shuttles start running at 5 every afternoon and they go nearly everywhere on campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are very few spots to park around campus that are free
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Being located extremely close to downtown Chicago makes it so that there is always something to do.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Tons of computer available at the library. Love it
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: I like to stay at the libraries the most. It is quiet place where I can concentrate on my work.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: There are diverse students attend in my school.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: I don't like to travel on winter because it takes so long to wait for the bus,especially when snow covers everywhere.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: There are numbers of buses and the train station is every close to school area.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Let's be real, you're coming to Chicago. In the winter it's cold, snowy, and windy. Everyone complains about it, but I don't think it's an actual issue for many people. You take the bus to class, all the buildings are heated of course, it isn't that big a deal. But bring proper winter attire for the love of god.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: unlimited computer access on campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: public transport. that is all.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: still a freshmen, haven't heard any complaints
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are various bus routes on/near campus, as well as ways to get to both the "L" and the commuter train lines. Taking the L or the Metra are the most common ways of getting downtown, but the Metra is definitely less sketchy. Some people have a car but there's barely any parking so it's really not common or very useful.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Great mix of old gothic buildings (Harper library, many classroom buildings, Hutch/Reynolds Club, some dorms) and new structures (other dorms, Mansueto, Logan, BSLC, Ratner, etc.)! The quad is the main green space and students hang out there doing homework, sleeping, reading in warm weather. The Midway also allows for midnight soccer and there's an ice rink there in the winter. Most dorms have a common lounge space (or more, depends) for its residents, along with a kitchen. Each house has its own personality and traditions, and many have weekly study breaks.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: During the school year it is usually cold here, however fall and spring do occur and are some of the most pleasant times of year both visually and in terms of temperature. The winter is definitely long, but it almost serves as a shared bonding experience. Don't get scared off because of the weather.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Chicago is an amazing city with a ton of restaurants, shops, cool neighborhoods, and things to do year-round. You can always discover something new. Hyde Park is pretty safe and has some great eating options, but the surrounding neighborhoods are not safe. That's the big tradeoff when it comes to going to school in an urban setting such as this one.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: All of our facilities are really nice and there's many that are very modern and nice looking though the whole campus has a very gothic feel to it. It really is a beautiful campus.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: We live about 20 minutes south of Chicago loop, that being said you can find something to do anytime. We're also about 5 minutes from Lake Michigan.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I love Chicago weather, but most people don't. There's definitely a good amount of wind, rain and will be snow.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I don't park, so I'm not entirely sure.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Hyde Park is a great place to live. It's a beautiful part of Chicago.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Super easy to get a hold of, and easy to use!!!!!!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Waiting for buses can take quite a while and can be confusing. Some city buses don't show up.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: This is coming from a person from the Midwest very used to 'weather,' at least the kind we get in Chicago. I love the seasons, especially the winter. It's always fun to see your friends from Texas experience snow for the first time. But don't worry, we definitely get all of the seasons here.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It's very expensive and a nightmare. There is free parking, but you're very lucky if you can find it.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It's Chicago! What else do I need to say? There is always something to do and there is always transportation to get to wherever you want to go.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The students at UChicago are awesome. I have met so many amazing people - they are beautiful, athletic, and intelligent. But the best thing about them is that they have that typical UChicago fascination with the world. They are all very opinionated (while still open-minded), well read, and ALWAYS ready to engage in an interesting discussion or debate. I think this quality is unique and it seems to be that most UChicago students have it.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Student life is what you make of it. When the weather is good many students hang out on the quad. It seems like there is a never ending soccer match on the Midway. Hyde Park is not the cutest town in the world. There are some nice restaurants and we just got a little theater. However, it's only like a 20 min. metra ride to the city. There are a lot of cool clubs to join and there are always fun activities and events going on across campus.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The winters can be brutal and the summers humid, but it's so beautiful to see the seasons change.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Chicago is an amazing city but the neighborhood of Hyde Park, while it is nice, is not the loop. Local eateries and attractions are fun places but it can be a little dull at times.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Chicago has a partnership with the CTA which means there are three public transit buses which take students through Hyde Park and are free to access. At night, the University provides three different shuttles which pick up in front of the library. It is pretty convenient to use and easily accessible.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: There are two parking garages for hospital and employee use. Most students who have cars live off campus and park in the alley ways by their building; parking on the main streets of campus is difficult, especially on the weekdays.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: For some, UC is like a second home.  For others, it is more like a boot camp.  The students are nerdy and friendly.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There are some amazing libraries and the architecture is outstanding.  The frat houses are mediocre, since the school and students generally tend towards funding academic organizations over social ones.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: great library, beautiful campus buildings, great aesthetics
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: parking is tough and tickets are imminent, get a bike
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Hyde Park is really coming up. There have been a lot of improvements since I first entered the College. However, I often find myself leaving the neighborhood for alternatives on the North Side and Downtown Chicago.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Hyde Park is quaint, but boring and a bit dangerous. It's a pain to get to the city, but there's a lot happening around campus.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: Bus or the elevated trains.  Both slow and cumbersome options.  They do run regularly, but for getting around campus, not very useful.  Walking or some personal transportation device like a bike is the best way.  Would be nice to have a car, but I am not sure how convenient it is to have one.  I didn't have one, but the parking seemed limited when I was there.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review:
Great equipment and labs.  Printing is available in all dorms, so are labs.  Never had any problems with the network or wireless access.

You can go without your own printer easily.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Campus is pretty dead.  You have to go downtown to do anything like sporting events, cultural events, shopping, etc.  It's a 30 minute bus ride at least.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Everyone is really nerdy and socially awkward. The number of normal people is rising but we're still the minority.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: The UC campus is interesting. The gothic architecture is beautiful, mixed with more modern buildings which are hit-or-miss. For example, our new Mansueto Library is top-notch, with a beautiful sky view and a below-ground book storage space. However, some of our dormitories (such as the Max East, Central, etc.) are gaudy and strange-looking. The athletics facilities are well-equipped and modern, good for what they are intended for.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Public transportation (CTA) is the easiest way to get around, however it can become costly ($2.25 a trip, no transfers). The options to get downtown are also very limited, as the bus and train stops are far and in very bad neighborhoods.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The Wifi is okay, but it's worse this year than last. It's nice to have your own computer, especially during midterms/finals.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Not only are you not allowed to have cars your first year, but even if you get one, there's no parking. Public transportation is gross and takes too long.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Usually a computer is available somewhere on campus for the students that need it. However, printing can become a hassle sometimes because there are not many available.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: ITS COLD. A lot. And dreary and rainy and windy. Bring rain boots and warm warm clothes
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: We have pretty great facilities and they've been updating them a lot recently. The Logan Arts Center has great resources, although some things you can't use without being enrolled in a class, which can be really annoying. Mansueto is new and beautiful (reading room/books housed underneath with a retrieving arm system).
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Dubbed as the place "fun goes to die," UChicago can be a bit overwhelming at times. The student body is very friendly and welcoming and everyone is excited to meet each other. The workload can be heavy at times, but there are always exciting, fun classes and the school is meant for people who want to be challenged and engage in rigorous mental activity. The University is currently doing large expansions with the opening of Mansueto Library and the current construction of the Logan arts center. The biggest downside for me is how cold it is!
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The student center is a vivid part of student' life. It provides facilities to countless student's organizations. There is a new gym and the library is just wonderful with brand new building with a huge study space.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I feel that there is a unique academic environment. "The life of mind" is very important. The study abroad programs are excellent. Doc films are unique.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The university campus is a great place to live. It could be a town on it's own. There are many cultural events going on, a lot of restaurants, a cinema ...
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Overall, campus life is pretty normal. There are a lot of student organizations, intramural sports, music groups, and etc. There are new state of the art athletic centers and libraries. The school sponsors events once in a while, such as a St. Patrick's Day party on campus. The weather isn't too cold, although it is windy at times. It's easy to get around with the shuttle bus system. Hyde Park is great because it's pretty safe (as long as you don't wander off) and has quite a few food places. Overall, while students do complain a lot about the workload, you can tell that they love it here.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Chicago is one of the greatest cities in the world, there's always something to do if you look. The only reason I didn't give an A+ is because while the immediate neighborhood is good as well, you have to take public transport to do most things.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The computer network is very fast and available all over campus.  The computers are very new, with updated software.  What college doesn't have good computer labs at this point?
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: There is an extensive shuttle system that'll send you around campus, to surrounding apartments, and the general Hyde Park area. To get out of Hyde Park into the downtown area or Chinatown, you can easily take the 5 bus that stops on campus and transfer to the Red line (train), which will take you anywhere you want to go.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: UChicago's campus is a designated botanical garden, so one can imagine the variety of green spaces in the area. Harper Library, recently renamed the Arley D. Cathey Learning Center, is reputed as one of the most beautiful college libraries in the world (think Hogwarts), and one of our newest libraries, called the Mansueto library, is a one-of-a-kind glass dome. There are plenty of cool places to study at as a result. On the south side of campus, the Reva and David Logan Center for the Arts just opened this past fall and boasts several music practice rooms, a woodshop, a state-of-the-art performance hall, and daily music and art events. Finally, Ratner and Henry Crown house all the gym equipment you'll need; if you prefer fresh air, the Promontory Point Park adjacent to Lake Michigan is a comfortable 15 minute jog away.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: UChicago is known for its idiosyncratic activities. The Scav Hunt, which occurs each Spring Quarter, is in the Guinness Book of World Records as the largest scavenger hunt in the world--and rightfully so, since items have included a homemade nuclear reactor and real, live zoo animals. We are also home to Kuvia, a weeklong winter tradition where students get up at early hours for cultural dance/sport activities; Kuvia culminates with a walk to Lake Michigan to do sun salutations during sunrise. Additionally, UChicago's career advancement programs have really expanded over the past few years--the Jeff Metcalf program now offers more than 500 paid summer internships for its students. With the city of Chicago as its backdrop, UChicago could not be any more special.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Parking is an absolute nightmare as the University also has a huge number of graduate students and employees who use up most of the parking. There are a number of pay lots, but parking passes are not available for all of them and are quite expensive. Public transportation is a better option for daily use, and parking is found most easily between 7 and 8AM, 12PM-1PM, and after 6PM on weekdays.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: UChicago has a campus bus system, night-time shuttle service, and access to the wider CTA system. Chicago's public transit system is one of the better in the country, but getting to and from Hyde Park can be difficult as the South Side is less connected than the North Side/Loop. As of June 2013, the CTA University bus routes (170, 171, 172) are being canceled, so transportation is likely to get worse. Most things in Hyde Park are within walking distance from campus and student apartment areas, but you should limit your night time travel.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Parking here is mostly free and easy to find, depending on where you're trying to park. There are also a few parking garages, but they cost money.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review:
Acceptable, if barely.

It is not infrequent to find that a majority of washing machines in the dorm basement are not working at some given time, that standard gym equipment is broken, missing, or never there to begin with, that one cannot find appointments with student care for another 3 weeks, and I could go on.

Conditions are livable, but EXTREMELY frustrating.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review:
Wireless is great for the most part. However, I live in South Campus, one of the more modern dorms, and the situation may be worse elsewhere. 99% of the campus has goo wireless from my experience.

The main library provides both a computer lab (with Linux and Mac), though there can be issues during CS labs finding an available computer, and loans out chargers, cameras, computers, etc. to students who need them.

It is best to bring your own computer, and a laptop at that, to college, be it UC or another.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review:
UChicago is unfortunately inconveniently far from downtown. The commute is an hour each way, and given the heavy academic load, most find this trip infrequently worth it. Thus, the downtown area is hardly local.

On Hyde Park itself, the community varies between two socioeconomic extremes, and thus some areas are bad while others are very nice. Basic street smarts and awareness can keep you out of trouble.

Finally, the area has a few (only a few) fun restaurants and shops, including the Med, some bookstores, and 53rd street.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Chicago, being the third-largest city, has more activity than one could crowd into a thousand lifetimes. The University of Chicago is in a very safe and ethnically-diverse neighborhood. Take the opportunity to explore not only Hyde Park, but the rest of the city as well.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Travel around Hyde Park is fairly good with free city buses that run on campus and free nightly shuttles that run from 5p-6am. It is less convenient to travel downtown or to other parts of Chicago, but public transportation is easy and straightforward.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The restaurants are plenty, but the number of shopping places is limited.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review:
For what you're paying, the facilities here are pretty nice. Not all dorms are created equal in terms of "niceness" but they are fantastic nonetheless. You really won't be complaining at all about the facilities (so long as you're not a whiny person to begin with)

The University has invested in better facilities and built newer ones in the past 5 years. It's a good blend of modern and traditional.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review:
You would have to be seriously out of touch with life if you think that UChicago, with all of its resources, location, and student vibrancy, would actually be the place "Where Fun Comes To Die". That phrase should tell you the school pride that the student body holds.

It's a great place to explore and find "your people". This place is hilarious and there are constantly lectures, activities, events to satisfy "The Life of the Mind". If you're bored, it's because you're a boring person. No school can help you there :/

RSO (club) life might leave something to be desired, but it's mostly because students allocate their time elsewhere, not that there is anything inherently wrong with the RSOs. People are generally apathetic towards Student Government, but the representatives themselves seem to be really into it.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's f****** cold winter quarter, but beyond that the weather doesn't make too much of a difference.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The weather is very capricious and unpredictable. It could be very chilly for a few days, but the next few days may be very sunny and warm. In general though, Chicago has a reputation for its weather. Though it may not be as bad as represented, it definitely does get pretty cold in the winter time.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The facilities are well maintained, and the availability of athletic equipment and library space is great for students. Nothing is too old or broken-down. Campus events are aplenty, it just depends on what you are interested in.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: it is awesome parking and good environment for everyone
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: We have multiple shuttles that run regular routes at night and we get free access to 3 public buses that run around campus during the day. The safe ride (shuttle that can pick you up anywhere) was eliminated this year, which really worries me!
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review:
You have the entire city of Chicago at your fingertips. And by "at your fingertips" I mean an 8 mile, 45 minute commute that costs $5.00 there and back. Unless you want to bike.

Downtown, or anywhere outside Hyde park where you won't be the immediate target of petty crime, is a hassle to get to. But it's there and great once you do get there. On weekends, the university also runs a shuttle service that makes it much easier.

Hyde Park, unfortunately, is not as great an atmosphere. There are few things to do, and the dining near campus is good, but not great.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There are many computer labs, and there is even a big mac lab. There are students that do not have any sort of computer at all (I do not recommend this but it is possible).
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The libraries have lots of computers and the only difficulty in gaining access to one is during a midterm or final. The network is spotty sometimes, so if you need to print something fast, you are better off using your own laptop. Overall though, I have no complaints about the computers here. Oh, and the network is crazy fast. Which is always a plus.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Not Worth It – Don't bring your car.  There's almost nowhere to park and you don't need it.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I came here because I knew the atmosphere would be weird. But sometimes its so weird that it just gets boring
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: They are mostly Macs and I have NO CLUE how to use them!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The internet speed can't be beat, but the tech support and general technological opportunities at this school are somewhat lacking. I never feel as though my information is safe on our computers, because a lot of the time the "log out" options don't work, passwords are saved when I opt not to have them saved, etc.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: A Great Neighborhood – Hyde Park gets trashed a bit more than I think it deserves. To start, the neighborhood is gorgeous. There are trees everywhere with beautiful building and houses. There are a bunch of unique neighborhood shops scattered about. The nightlife is pretty quiet, but there are a couple of bars around. There are parks seemingly everywhere, including the Point, which shoots out into the middle of the lake and includes bonfire pits and a beach. In addition, Hyde Park is going through a lot of development, with a slew of restaurants, retail options and a movie theater all coming to campus this year if the rumors hold true. In general, Hyde Park feels more like a neighborhood than a college town. Some people don't enjoy that, but I for one think it's a great place to live.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Everyone Has Their Own – Everyone pretty much has their own computer, but in terms of tech support, wifi availability, and a smooth printing system, UChicao gets an A!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: No Need for a Car – Just get a bike or a CTA card and you'll be great. Otherwise, the parking is okay- pretty crowded but freeee!
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Always Free Wifi or Computer to Use – There are plenty of computer labs, the internet is SO reliable and you can even check out fancy macbooks from the librarys for days at a time!
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Pretty Good All Around – There are computer labs in each of the dorms, so it's theoretically possible to survive without one, but I can't really imagine doing so. That's not anything to do with UChicago though, I just couldn't imagine living without a computer you own. Laptops are not necessarily a must, but I would highly recommend one over a desktop. WiFi coverage is pretty good across campus.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Chicago definitely has pretty intense weather, snow storms in the winter, killer heat in the summer. But I really enjoy the snow and excitement of winter, coming from a place where I never get snow. The campus is beautiful in the snow even in the overcast sky, and walking to class while a light snow starts to fall is one of the prettiest experiences of my life.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Too Much to Do – Chicago is one of the best cities in the world, stock full of culture and great food, you'll never not find stuff going on for you to do. It's also easy to get downtown from campus using the Metra, you'll be there in 15 minutes.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Buses Are Excellent. They're changing the way SafeRide operates for 2012-2013. Instead of SafeRide they are going to just add more bus routes. The routes are super easy to memorize, you get access to CTA buses that go through Hyde Park for free. And CTA is super reliable in terms of getting downtown and around Chicago, at least compared to where I'm from.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Macs Suck – I hate macs and most of the computers at the school are macs so I find them hard to use because I have a Toshiba laptop. But they are nice and up to date and do not randomly shut off on you.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Getting Around Campus Is Easy – Getting around campus on the shuttle system is fairly easy, with regular shuttles that cover most of campus running for most of the evening into the late night (and on weekends early morning).  Getting downtown can be a hassle late at night, but other than that there are a few buses, the red-line/green-line (which are a little dangerous) and the metra, all for less than $3.  Also, a taxi downtown is normally a very reasonable $15.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: It's up to You – UChicago is in Chicago, but what the brochures don't tell you is that it's in Hyde Park, which is about 45 minutes outside of downtown on public transit when it's all said and done. Do not let this discourage you! Chicago is a beautiful city with so much going on. It is up to you to get downtown or to the northside. Break the bubble!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore
