Campus.Review: Very Good,  but They Are Discontinuing Safe-Ride – However there are shuttles, buses, and police umbrella services.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: but it suits our work ethic. Also, there's a certain comradeship that comes with it as well. Uchicago dosn't offer a 'soft' collegiac experience in any way, so if this scares you you probably aren't cut out for this school anyway.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: You don't really need a car, but if you want to have one its easy to find parking, you just need to buy a permit
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Okay Printers – Regenstein and Crerar Libraries have plenty of computers, mostly new, though they can get crowded during finals. Cheapish printers are convenient, and you can even print online from your own computer (but this is sometimes down). WiFi is spotty but workable, and most everyone does use laptops (although classes don't really seem to need them).
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Creating Fun – The university has a reputation of being too difficult to maintain a social life, but that is not the case at all. It is a rigorous academic institution with a somewhat accelerated schedule due to the quarter system, but there are many opportunities to get involved in campus life through student organizations, community service, and the activities that students come up with themselves to spice things up. One of the things that has really caught on is the school wide game/contest scene. It borrows on the structure of one of the hallmark traditions called "Scav", which is a dorm-team scavenger hunt where you make the things on "the list". These other games like Assassins and Humans vs. Zombies organized by students make things interesting on the quad and in the dorms.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Getting Here and There – On campus there are a few bus routes that ride around the university community every 20 minutes during the day. Then at night there are shuttles that run routes to the north east and south of campus. There is also a service for people to use during the late night which you can call for pick-up.  The campus is small enough though that you can get to anywhere from the perimeter within 20 minutes.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Use of Own Computer – I typically use my own computer, whether in my dorm or in the library. It appears as though there is plenty of computer availability in the libraries and computer labs for those who require them.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Good City, Bad Reputation – Chicago is a wonderful city with tons of things to do. When studies get to be too much, it costs about 2 bucks for a trip downtown which has all the shopping you could ever want, tourist traps to impress visitors, fun secrets to share with friends, and a good nightlife. The only problem is that University of Chicago students are perceived to be boring and antisocial, which isn't true with most of us.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Come Here, You'll See – We're quirky, eccentric and a little insane sometimes, but our passion for academics cannot be beat. I encourage visiting. You'll know right away if it's the place for you or not. It was for me!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Printing sometimes doesn't work, occasionally the internet is a little slow, but overall things are reliable.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Cultural Oasis – Hyde Park offers a lot to students, from shopping and sight-seeing, outdoor recreation on Lake Michigan to plays, concerts and art exhibitions. Almost every weekend, there is something to do, although many students are too busy studying to take advantage of all of it. We are also trying to become more aware of the disadvantage of many areas that surround us in South Chicago, and many community outreach programs work on the South side.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Great when you need them, which is more or less always. Nice Windows quad, Mac Quad, and a variety of Debian machines to SSH into if you need to do so.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Hyde Park is a nice place, as are the surrounding neighborhoods. There are a few places to eat at and it's nice to walk around...oh, and there's Chicago..
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Just Don't Bring a Car – Parking near campus any time after 8am or before 6pm is generally a nightmare.  Most students, therefore, choose to walk or bike instead of driving.  Students who do own cars mostly use them to explore the rest of Chicago, as Hyde Park is very pedestrian-friendly.  In general, though, Chicago has great public transit, so a car is really superfluous.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Best of All Possible Worlds – Here at U of C we get a combination of things that not a lot of other schools can offer: unbelievable academics that'll change the way you think, a great city with countless opportunities, a small college-town with everything that goes into that, and, contrary to popular belief, tons of fun (yes, normal, actual college fun).
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Best of Both Worlds – We get the best of both worlds here at U of C. We in the shadow of downtown and all that it has to offer (which is a LOT), but Hyde Park is just far enough away to truly be a small, residential college town. The University is an important part of the community, with most of our professors living in Hyde Park, and the community is excited to have us. Lots of good restaurants, coffee shops, bookstores, etc. (and more coming soon!) And Chicago? Pound for pound one of the best cities in the world I think- so much to do, so easy to do it, and the school has hooked us up with lots of exclusive, unbelievable discounts.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Wifi Is Reliable and Everywhere – The entire campus (even outside and the gyms) are wireless, which means you can really work anywhere. The Computers in the Computer Labs have pretty much any program you might need for a class (like Econ or Stats) so you don't have to buy the program if you don't have it.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Several libraries on campus are great when you need a quiet place to study
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Huge Rush to Print Just Before Class Starts – There is usually a rush in the computer labs with people printing just before class starts. However, with your own computer hooked up to WiFi you can print directly without needing the lab computers.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The Libraries Are Gorgeous – That's the thing about UChicago - you're going to spend a lot of time in the library, and you're going to find it a pretty beautiful place to be. Whether you like the minimalist brutalism of the Regenstein, the glass-domed clarity of the Mansueto, or the old-word grandeur of Harper, there's always somewhere to suit your mood and your homework.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Public Transportation – You can park. Overpriced parking garage, or street parking if you're lucky - can get crowded in busier hours. If you can avoid it, just take public transportation down here, or bring your patience.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: A lot of the computers here are PCs running a pre-Vista version of Windows that, although suffices, doesn't inspire a great deal of recreational or intense computer use. The Mac labs are adequate and from what I hear, students can print for free in some of them. Some dorms have their own computer rooms and most major locations on campus feature printers/copy machines connected to a unified printing network which allows students to upload documents and then print them at a specified location.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Great Academic Programs – The core program at chicago is exceptional, and the students are engaging and interesting. The teachers present lots of good opportunities for students.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Available Buses Around Campus but Elsewhere Is Less Convenient – Getting to downtown Chicago is hassle, especially if you live away from the 55 or the 6 bus.  However, transportation around campus is fine, but is barely ever necessary. The late night shuttles are very useful, as well as the safe-ride option
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Good but Not Great – The facilities are for the most part good. The gyms are nice, although not massive. The libraries are nice, and there are plenty of spots to study
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Decent, Good Wifi – The printers are reliable, although it is hard to refill your printing card. The wifi network is extremely reliable, and pretty fast. It is almost necessary to have your own computer, but you can get by without your own printer.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review:
In general, the University of Chicago is a breathtaking campus.  The facilities are wonderful.  However, as a law student, I was somewhat disappointed with the law school architecture and
general facilities.  It does not compare with the rest of the undergraduate school facilities.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Wireless Is Good, Everything Else Is Okay – The wireless on campus is perfectly fine, and with most students having laptops, smartphones, iPads, etc., it is very easy to gain access to the internet. The printers are okay, although they often break, but there are enough of them that it is not a huge problem. Computer labs are available throughout campus
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Fairly Convenient – The college runs shuttles at all hours of the day, some dorms are close to a CTA bus station that you can take to the subway downtown pretty easily. It's helpful if you have a bike, especially if you're living in one of the farther dorms.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's Chicago. You can't expect weather like Miami or LA. Frankly, the Winters are brutal. The temperatures are on par with most of the rest of the mid-west, but the University is very close to Lake Michigan and the wind really makes the difference. It is very important to cover your face and hands when it gets particularly fierce. Your exposure to the weather can vary significantly depending on where you live and how long your walk to campus is. (Snell-Hitchcock and Max P are just a few steps, I live off-campus and it is nearly a mile if I don't use University Transportation [which is a life saver]). Despite this, Autumn in Chicago is amazing and the campus is absolutely breathtaking every day of the year, plus we actually have a beach (yes, you read that correctly) and a number of great parks and green spaces for the warmer months.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: What else do I have to say? It's a great city and safety in Hyde Park isn't an issue if you have some common sense.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's Chicago. But we have a relatively small campus and if you dress properly you will be fine.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Get Off Campus! Relations with the nearby area are not the best, as the University has taken some actions that have caused a strained relationship between it and the rest of Hyde Park.  But that doesn't mean you can't find super fun things to do off campus!  Downtown is full of great things to do, even a short trip on the Red Line can get you to a mecca of restaurants and movie theatres.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Hyde Park is a really cool neighborhood located on the South Side of Chicago.  It has a college town feel, since the University is inseparable from the community, but all of the benefits of a huge city are a short ride away.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It Has Everything! Chicago is a great city with everything you could possibly imagine. From sporting events to the countless museums to the Opera House and Symphony Hall, there is always something to do. Visit many museums for free on UChicago's free arts pass!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Getting around campus is really easy because the two CTA buses that circulate the campus are free for students and faculty. I ride my bike almost everywhere. The University has a free shuttle system that makes getting around campus and the neighborhood really easy. During times when lots of people are travelling to the airports they provide free shuttles too!
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Little Need for a Car on Campus – Everything is within walking distance or biking distance from everything else so a car isn't really necessary. Very few students use them to get to class because most people just walk or bike from their dorms or apartments. The CTA buses that circulate campus are free for students which makes getting around the neighborhood really easy. Also, the University runs really convenient shuttles every evening. Sometimes it would be nice to have a car to get to other neighborhoods of Chicago but pretty much everything can be accessed on the CTA without too much trouble.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Free busses during the day, free shuttles all night, plus a van that will take you door to door anywhere in the neighborhood anytime.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Campus is walkable and the city has great public transit, so you don't really need a car (most students don't have one).
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Chicago's neighborhoods offer its residents a chance to experience so many cultures. The arts scene in this city is incredible. The night life is active. And as far as parks go, you can't beat the huge number of them in this city.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: As someone who was a double-major here and still had time to hold down two jobs (one at a museum on campus and one at the office of Multicultural Student Affairs), sleep, have a life, be involved in my house's IM teams, and get ok grades, I had an amazing time at UChicago. There really is something for everybody here, whether you are interested in Greek life, sports, community service, or just really focused on your studies. It is easy to get a job on campus (even if you are not a work-study student), and people are really genuinely welcoming when you get to campus (even the upperclassmen). The Metcalf internships over the summer are amazing - you can do what would pretty much always be an unpaid internship over the summer, but you get a stipend to live off of while you do the internship, so you can actually make money!
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: No Place Better – I loved my time at UChicago. Yes, you're coming here to work hard, and you will-- classes are intense and you'll be expected to learn a lot. There isn't grade inflation here, so you will work for your A, although it is still possible to get one (or many) if you're willing to put in the effort.  You'll come out with a really unparalleled academic experience in my opinion. Outside of class, PEOPLE DO REALLY HAVE FUN!! This is not the kind of school where "fun" is 60,000 people tailgating a football game, but if you want to have great conversations, an awesome housing community, lots of interesting things to do (clubs, large events like Scav Hunt or cultural shows, and hey, anything that the awesome city of Chicago has for you to do, and some parties) this is the perfect place to be. Don't believe the "where fun comes to die" rumors-- while we work really hard, this IS a fun place to be.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Ratner Athletics Center – The Cardio rotunda is great for using treadmills or elliptical machines. There are TVs and headphone jacks on the machines so you can catch up on TV while you run too! The pool is awesome (Olympic-sized), but make sure to check the schedule before you go, since the hours change when the swim team has practice there. The locker rooms are pretty clean, and there's a machine that will whip your swimsuit around in it until it dries (which I think is pretty convenient - no soggy gym bag on your way home!).
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Totally Hogwartsian – UChicago has amazing architecture, some more modern, but a lot in that great neo-gothic feel.  It really looks a lot like Hogwarts. A number of the newer buildings (including the Mansueto Library, which looks like it comes from space, and Max P, a dorm covered in orange) are great newer spaces. The Ratner Athletic Center is a great place to go work out as well. Only reservation is that some of the older dorms are a little run down.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Neo-Gothic Paradise – Whether you're looking for a dormitory with a parapet, or a glass and steel residence hall, the campus creates a fluid and beautiful combination of both styles.  The central quads retain their unadulterated 1900s look, while the outer stretches offer modernity and technology.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: You'd Think That We'd Have Better – For a top ten university, you would think our computer resources would be better. We still have systems running Windows 2000. Why is that?
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Available, Not Always Convenient – Many people have cars, and while street parking can get crowded during the day, many either 1) opt to pay for a permit in the parking garage (which is awesome) or 2) wait until non-peak hours (after 5ish) to use street parking.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It's Fun! Everyone has heard that Chicago has cold, windy, snowy winters and hot, humid summers.  As a fan of the cold, I find the winters quite bearable.  Though it can get bitter, we had two snow days this past year after a blizzard, and everybody loves a good snow day.  The fall and spring are beautiful in Hyde Park and definitely redeem the coldest of winter's nights.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: CTA Is OK – Public transportation is pretty good around the university.  A few routes of the CTA are free for students and can get you to some great locations in Hyde Park.  The university also has late night shuttles to help off campus residents get back to their homes when it is dark out.  The CTA 6 bus can get you straight to Michigan Avenue, though it does take about 20-30 minutes.  The Red Line is out of the way and a bit dangerous at night but helpful if you are traveling further north!
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Hyde Park – There's a lot of hate about Hyde Park regarding the atmosphere and the nightlife.  Yes, Hyde Park can get dangerous.  Just across from where I live, my friend was mugged at gun point.  And two of our bikes were stolen on our first night in the new apartment.  Regardless, there's so much going on, whether that be frat parties, apartment get-togethers, and little festivals that nobody knows about.  And there's always something going on Chicago whether that be little hipster musical festivals or big club/bar events.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Two campus gyms provide whatever you could want, two museums and one professional theater on campus as well as tons of student performance venues make us a great place for the arts (with the Logan Center on the way next year too). The Reynolds Club and meeting spaces across campus provide plenty of options for organizations to meet and students to hangout, and of course the diversity of libraries provide a center of activity at all times. The neo-gothic look of th campus is classy as s***.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Plenty of Computer Access but Expensive Printing – Most people have their own computers, with ethernet in dorms and wifi all across campus, but there is 24-7 access to computers in dorms and the Regenstein library as well as computing and printing stations all across campus. Computers come with full current versions of every advanced statistical package I've ever needed. Printing on campus is $0.10 per page however, which is a bit steep.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Underappreciated Student Town – Chicago doesn't  get enough credit for being college student-friendly. Lots of museums and other attractions have student free days, restaurants have student discounts, and because there is such a high density of colleges and universities in the cities (and then northwestern just in the suburbs) there's a large crowd of 18-23 year olds to hang out with. The city is also great because especially during the warmer months, there are tons of free things to do (free museum days, music festivals, art expos etc). The shopping ranges from pretty high end (like the 900 on north michigan/boutiques on mag mile) to thrift stores around Pilsen and Uptown. There's a big sports culture here, with the Sox, Cubs, Blackhawks, Bears, Bulls and Fire being a big part of the Chicago city pride. Students aside, Chicago is a very culturally diverse town with tons of little cultural neighborhoods that are great to visit as well. Unlike other cities like say, New York, it's not as elitist, rushed, crowded or dirty. CTA transport is extremely affordable, and ZipCar and the local iGo car sharing services make travel around the city easy too. This was definitely the place to be an independent adult for the first time.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: RIGHT on campus it's hard to park.  But there is plenty of space just a few blocks away, and the university has a huge parking building on the north end of campus.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review:
Winters Are Rough, but Spring Is Wonderful! Winter is really cold, especially since you have to walk everywhere in Chicago...but, seriously if you're picking your school based on the weather alone, then I think you need to evaluate your priorities.

But oh, Chicago/campus in spring and summer is a sight to behold.  Those first nice days of spring are wonderful...the WHOLE campus just lays on the gorgeous quads and soaks in the sun.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Campus Strictness – The university really wants you to have fun, and they are not concerned with getting students in trouble for things like drinking. They want you to be safe, but don't mind kids walking around dorms with beer.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: We are the ONLY college in Chicago that does not have U-Pass, where we can use public transportation for free.  It is absolutely ridiculously, considering our tuition is the highest and that so many students have internships downtown.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Good Bus System – There's really no cost. There's a good shuttle bus system after 6PM. Day-time options are provided by the CTA (no cost as well) but can get very crowded during rush hours.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Libraries Galore – We legitimately have libraries next to libraries at UChicago. With the new Mansueto Library built next to the Regenstein Library, students have access to an innovate, different architechture in which to study. Study Commons are spread across the campus as well, allowing students options for different study breaks. On top of that, the libraries and study commons are stocked with couches and plush chairs, a definite hot spot to take the much needed nap following class after having just pulled the all-nighter.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Great Wifi..Even Outside on the Quad! I think the title pretty much explains it all...you can get wireless Internet connection ANYWHERE, even if you want to do work outside, relaxing on the grass of the quad.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The Social Scene – There's a lot I could say about how academically awesome the school is, which it is. But who cares.  You obviously already know that if you're even looking into Uchicago.  What a lot of people don't know is that Uchicago is actually really fun.  If you make an effort to meet people and go out-- the frats, downtown, house parties, etc-- the social scene can kind of rock. I grew up in a campus town (U of I) and just because it's huge doesnt mean it'll be more fun. The quaintness of the social scene makes it that much better.  There aren't as many people that drink or go out, but the quality of the people that do are pretty exceptional. Basically, we're more fun that everyone gives us credit for...promise.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Parking on campus is surprising easily (NOTE: not in the mornings though.. why? I don't know) I've only gotten one ticket.  Practice your parallel parking techniques, they'll come in handy in Chicago, trust me.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review:
Hyde Park – Hyde Park is essentially an enclave in the south side of Chicago. That being said, Hyde Park itself is great in the sense that it is a urban community community entirely constructed around the University of Chicago. That is to say, it isn't highly commercialized and the establishments that do appear exist to serve the University community. Overall very peaceful and a times a bit utopic. 

That being said, Hyde Park is quite a distance from downtown and a serious commute to the northside. Any desire to go shopping, attend non-UofC cultural events, or go clubbing will require more planning and overall commitment. Overall, those coming to UChicago should not have it be a necessity to be located in the heart of commercial Chicago.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Most areas do not have parking meters. Sometimes it is hard to find a place to park close to campus though. Apartments generally having parking lots or parking space near them. Having a car is not a nuisance, but is not a necessity either.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Nerds, Nerds, Nerds – The University of Chicago is a very unique place, and it takes a very unique person to enjoy the intense atmosphere and challenging UC curriculum. That being said, most of the students would be considered the typical "nerds" at any other school. The athletic events have minimal turnouts, whereas the library is the place to be. The Regenstein library looms like a concrete prison until the flowers around it blossom in Spring. The new addition to the Reg, the Joe and Rita Mansueto library glints in the sun like a glass spaceship who's beauty seems out of place next to the old, ivy-covered quadrangle buildings that many students liken to Harry Potter's Hogwarts. The UNiversity of Chicago, "where fun comes to die," is a magnificent school that can be liked to no other.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: You have access to one of the world's great cities.  Chicago is home to amazing cuisine, nightlife, tourist attractions, cultural attractions and more.  Awesome place to live.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Generally Pretty Good – There is a lot of nighttime bus routes and Safe Ride.  The routes are pretty good but Safe Ride is usually late.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: The Horror, the Horror. Snow and wind. More snow, more wind. Spring quarter is usually pretty nice though.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Winter Sucks, Rest Is Great – Winter will make you want to die. Cold windy neverending. But spring and fall are beautiful, and summer makes it entirely worth it.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: There are a good amount of computers if you need them. There's a designated Mac/Linux lab for those that need those OS's for certain projects. Printing is fine, although free printing was revoked 2 years ago. The network is fantastic and there is wireless across the entire campus. Personal printers make life much easier.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Depends Where You're Going. We've got everything from buses to trains to the "L", taxis, and car rental clubs. If you need to get somewhere you have tons of options. However, some forms of transportation are better than others. Getting downtown take the red line or the metra but getting back, the easiest way is to use the buses.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: DON'T GET a CAR – There is no need for a car because public transit is so good in Chicago and parking everywhere is so expensive.  I live downtown and commute to school and work everyday and the stress of parking and paying sometimes 40$ for parking would make my life miserable.  Just take the train or the bus.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Printing on Campus – Printing costs at least 10 cents and always takes tons of time.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Best Education – Chicago really does provide you with one of the best educations you can get anywhere. You learn so much and are set up to be very successful in the real world. At times it does suck with all the academic work but in the end its worth it and very gratifying
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Winter Is Too Long – I'm from Florida, so I thought I might turn into an icicle. The winter really isn't that bad, as long as you have the proper coat, boots, scarves and gloves. The worst part about the winter is how dark it gets.  The sun sets around 4 pm and it's really depressing. It's also annoying that the winter lasts so long.  When it's snowing in April, you feel like the world hates you. But then, spring comes and the flowers bloom and the trees turn green and it's beautiful and magical and life is good! Fall is also really nice because it's not too cold and the leaves turn, so the quad is ablaze with orange, gold, and red. The first few snows are really fun, and there tend to be snowball fights on the quad. When the snow freezes into muddy ice, then it's not as fun. But, there are plenty of fun campus activities in the winter to keep you distracted.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review:
I Love the Library! I literally love the library. We have a bunch of libraries to choose from: The Harper Reading room looks like it should be a Harry Potter film set, the Reg is ugly and somewhat depressing but you get a lot of work done (and you can see the Chicago skyline from the 5th floor). The Mansueto (aka Man Sweat aka Bibliodome aka RegEgg) just opened and is sleek and modern, and Crerar is great too. The libraries are always clean and well maintained. 
The gyms are great too, especially Ratner. It has an olympic-sized indoor pool, basketball courts, dance practice rooms, weightlifting and other exercise equipment, and plenty of treadmills and elliptical machines... so many that I've never had to wait for one to be free. Henry Crown gym is a bit older and run down, but has an indoor track and even more treadmills and exercise machines, and is conveniently located between two dining halls. 
The Reynolds club (student center) has the beautiful Mandel Hall, where large performances take place, and also the third floor theater for smaller performances. It is also home to the UChicago seal (don't step on it) and an Einstein Brothers cafe. The cafe sells huge, delicious $1 milkshakes every Wednesday and there is a beautiful courtyard where you can slurp them up on warm days. 
In general, campus is beautiful. The main quad is especially Hogwarts-like. I love the Gothic architecture and in the fall the colorful leaves on the trees are just so picturesque! 
Classrooms are fine for the most part, some are a little small and some buildings don't have air conditioning, which is fine for most of the year but gets pretty miserable around May.
Overall though, this place is SO BEAUTIFUL!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The city of Chicago is great, but the winters are cold and dark! It starts cooling off around the end of November and stays cold through April. It snows a lot, but the campus actually does a very good job with the shoveling and salting of sidewalks.  Even in the blizzard of 2011, the sidewalks were clear enough to walk on.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Chicago is an amazing city that is easily accessible within 20 minutes from campus via the CTA or Metra. There are so many good restaurants (check out Chinatown and Greektown)! The Art Institute is incredible, and UChicago students get free admission. The Lincoln Park Zoo is another cool free attraction, and many museums (such as the Field Museum) have free days at least once a month. Hyde Park, the neighborhood where UChicago is located, is not quite as awesome. Everything closes at 9 or 10 pm, so if you get hungry late on a Saturday night, your options are Walgreens (open 24 hrs) or Bartmart (the campus convenience store)... Pretty slim pickings. There aren't really people out and about doing things, unless it's an event on campus. I recommend you escape to the city as often as possible!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Could Be Better – buses are available but the university needs to give the students a u-pass
Campus.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Though I'm only a sophomore, it is already very clear that the university has incredible alumni network, and a group of career advisers that are dedicated to helping students leave UChicago with a job/arrangements. There are tons of great internships available, and plenty of advisers and faculty/staff to help students find opportunities. From what I've been told, graduating with a degree from the University of Chicago is a huge bonus for anyone looking for a job, etc. The school's career services are really top of the line!
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It is helpful, but can be easy to overlook
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Everyone I know has been able to land internships and part-time jobs in their areas of interest, and most go on to jobs that they love after graduation.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: A degree from this school is very helpful in the job market, according to all my outside sources.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: One of the best Universities in the world
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: A degree from UChicago is something that employers love to see.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I am a first year undecided major. No useful comment.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Depends on major and grades etc. but we're all gonna be a-ok
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The Ivies probably have better job networks. The value of a degree definitely varies. Economics, math, statistics, chemistry, physics, etc. are all going to be highly valued.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: You will have a very valuable degree after graduating.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Degrees from UChicago are impressive and will get you plenty of job offers, provided you have a reasonable GPA.  There are some recruitment efforts on campus, and the University maintains a large online database of job offers targeted at current and former students.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: You are provided with all the resources you need to go places after college.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Amazing career center and job prospects.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: There are recruitment events all the time. The career planning advisors don't really reach out to you, so you have to do your planning and follow things.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: There are great resources for finding jobs and a lot of networking opportunities. It doesn't hurt that this is a top 5 school in the country.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: They don't really give out aid. I didn't get any, and a lot of my friends couldn't come here because they couldn't get aid either.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The University gives aid, but often not enough.  From what I can tell, it's a bit behind its peer institutions in terms of aid generosity.  But the Odyssey Scholarships are great, and it's easily the top institution to offer merit-based financial aid to undergrads.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: I did not apply for financial aid, but would appreciate more merit scholarships.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: It was cheaper for me to go here than most other state schools.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Received more aid here than any other school, both need-based and merit.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: From what I saw at the orientation there are quite a bit of internships available.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: While I had a lot of forms to fill out and the process was tedious, I always received the financial aid I needed. When I petitioned the school to ask for a raise my scholarship, they did and have been increibly accommodating.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Wouldn't go anywhere else. What a university. This place occupies a very special place in American higher education.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I didn't have a problem my first year. They covered half my costs which was great, as there was no way in hell I could afford this place without financial aid. It's quite expensive to attend school here, but you are going to get arguably the best education available in the United States, so it's worth it.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Recruiting and career prospects couldn't better, there is a large and well-funded program dedicated to getting students through this without getting in the way of enjoying college and learning new things. People from Chicago are world leaders in many fields. CEOs of Microsoft, Goldman Sachs, Paramount Pictures, Chevron, IBM, you name it.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Built into the application with minimum additional hassle
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: They truly do help low-income students out as much as possible, with the University of Chicago grant and the new Odyssey Scholarship. The financial aid process if confusing, but they come through.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The financial aid process was a bit of a hassle because of the tedious applications, but the school was very generous to me and my family and I ended up getting what I needed in order to attend. My advice would be to not be afraid to ask if there is potential to receive more scholarships - I got an extra $5,000 a year just by asking.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The university grants a ton of financial aid (around $90 million a year), but if you choose to move off campus just remember that they stop giving aid for housing costs.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: There are a lot of forms, but the people at the financial aid office are very helpful.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: They're really great with scholarships. After I was admitted, I explained my financial situation to my admissions counselor and he was able to get me the additional scholarship that I needed to come. And my package wasn't half bad before that. It was definitely the reason why I came.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Without the university's financial aid package, I would not be able to attend
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I ended up having a lot of aid, and without it I would not be able to attend
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I was given the maximum that my school gives out, but it still didn't cover the full cost of attendance, making it difficult for me to pay tuition.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: UChicago has lots of money and is very understanding of students' socioeconomic situations.
Value.Author: Niche User

Value.Review: I don't personally need aid. The experiences of friends range from good to unspeakably bad.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It's pretty easy to apply for, but they're rather stingy. If you're low income then you probably have a pretty good shot of getting what you need, but middle-class kids tend to get a little screwed. You can probably get financial aid, you just won't get all that much. They readjust each year depending on your parents tax returns from the previous year, so it's flexible, just don't expect big packages.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: I received a little financial aid, less than I should have really though.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I'm a Questbridge scholar, so full ride.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The financial aid process was smooth and easy mostly because the office was quick to respond and were extremely helpful in answering all of my concern. Although that being said, I did not receive all the financial aid I needed.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Applying for financial aid was simple and I got a good amount my first year. However, financial aid for my second year my largely worse. In fact, I have the feeling that they offer generous financial aid to bait in new students, then significantly reduce that aid the second year so students are forced to either pay more or leave. Be very wary of the University of Chicago's financial aid.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The initial process did not go through smoothly. I and others feel that the University is very strict on its rules and does not handle unusual student situations well.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: About an average amount of student financial aid on an extremely large tuition.  Since there are so many brilliant students, it is hard to stand out here and receive extra academic scholarship money.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: The University of Chicago has been noticeably increasing their financial aid packages. They are truly emphasizing college affordability and making efforts to match their peer institutions in debt policies, aid packages, and general information to applying families.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I was estimated to receive $22,000 in aid, and ended up with absolutely nothing. Financial aid is stingy, and its not uncommon to have to fight for some money. With the $60,000+ price tag, really think about if it's worth it. You will have a great education, but the stress, social environment, and cost may not be worth it.
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: Merit aid is very good accesible to more people than just geniuses, and I received a wonderful 15k a year package. No additional app, just ask
Value.Author: College Student

Value.Review: UChicago gave me a wonderful financial aid package, but it was a bit of a hassle trying to slog through all of that paperwork.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Aid is entirely need based. They are very generous if you're household income is below 100,000 or thereabouts, but if you're a middle income family with a sibling in or out of college you're out of luck.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I would say that most schools are looking to find as many students as possible who do not need financial aid. However, it should not be too hard to apply for, though maybe the portion of money you receive might not be too great. Especially since the tuition for UChicago is one of the highest in the country.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: For internation students, it is hard to get a decent financial aid.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: I'm on scholarship, and the grant given to me by the school was pretty generous. In fact, I often go so far as to say that it was the deciding factor leading to my enrollment. I lost some federal money this year, but the school can't really do much about that.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It's Always Tricky – Financial aid is always a headache, but I don't think it's really specific to this school.  I will say that I was on multiple occasions told something about financial aid or promised something by one person, and then another person in the university would contradict what I had been told earlier.  I think this goes for ANY school you apply to: EVERY SINGLE TIME you talk to ANYONE about financial aid, write down their name, the date, and a quick summary of what they say.  Then say it back to them and ask them if this is correct.  That way you keep a record of what you're told or promised.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: The financial aid office does a great job at providing scholarships to students here, both need-based and merit-based. One would be surprised to know exactly how many students are receiving financial aid.. it's quite a few.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Have to Dig – It's hard to get info and hard to get proper need based scholarships from certain income brackets. You have to go through a lot of paperwork and hoops.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: International students and those from higher income families are paying nearly, if not full, tuition. Lack of money however is not a reason to avoid considering U of C. There are several scholarships available to students as well as many opportunities to work on campus.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: My financial aid has been great. The people have always been really nice when I've gone in to ask questions and the package I've received really fits my situation and allows me to go to school here.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Slightly on the Stingy Side. Title says it all. They do give you money, but more on the sparse side.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Merit and Need – The University does an outstanding job recognizing qualified students for hefty merit scholarships, and need based aid goes to many.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The school has a lot of donors that provide aid for students who need it. I received plenty of money from donors of the school, which definitely made the cost of this school be very affordable. They also offer academic scholarships but be sure to apply early. Besides that, the aid is there, all you have to do is apply for it.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: You Got to Be Smart – you got to be really smart to get merit scholarship
Value.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I like the food in Hyde Park and it's easy enough to access the city and surrounding neighborhoods if you're bored of it.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: It's not inedible but it isn't great either. Choices are boring and bland and basically always the same and it's super overpriced.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Expensive, but it's Chicago. You can find anything you want.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Doesn't taste good, never have plates or silverware, too salty, no good vegetarian protein options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: A good number of interesting ethnic options - Mediterranean, Thai, Indian, sushi, Mexican, Italian, to name a few.  Harold's Chicken is dirt-cheap and tastes absolutely heavenly, but it's loaded with grease and salt.  Walgreen's and CVS are both open 24/7 in the area and have some basic snacks.  Hyde Park Produce is awesome for cheap fresh produce, but the rest of their stuff is rather overpriced.  The only real grocery store in Hyde Park is Treasure Island, which is huge and has lots of options but is again overpriced and also fairly far from campus.  I usually only go there for meat and specialty stuff and stick to Hyde Park Produce, CVS, and this little Middle Eastern grocery called Valley of Jordan for everything else.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: People here are always complaining about the food, but it's actually quite good, if a bit overpriced.  There's a bit of a crunch right now because Pierce dining hall was taken down and the new one isn't built yet, so the dining halls get very crowded, in particular Bartlett.  Staff are friendly, and all-you-can-eat is perfect for college students, as is Fourth Meal.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Cafes are god, but in general the dining halls are bad. Aramark is understaffed, underserviced, food is bad, bugs show up in food sometimes. Utensils are often dirty and missing.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Chicago is an excellent place to find new, cultural cuisines.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I love the variety and availability of fresh produce. There are cuisines from many different cultures and there are stations that make for good old stand-bys.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Off-campus dining is pretty good, Hyde Park has a lot and if you go downtown there's even more.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Dining halls are pretty bad.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Harold's is always popular and there are many places like the Med to go to.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There is a great variety of off campus dining options especially if you are willing to venture out of the immediate college area. Even within the campus area there is good variety.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Now that I love in an apartment, I miss having the option of the dining halls. South is a good option for a dining hall and pierce was, especially for fourth meal (RIP). The Reynolds club has the best on campus options with hutch commons and Einstein bros.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: There are a lot of options for off-campus dining. Hyde Park has some work to do but downtown ... it's Chicago.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Not bad. There is a pretty wide variety of food in the dining halls, and if you ever tire of the dining halls, the whole city of chicago is your playground.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Hyde park has lots to offer in terms of restaurants off campus. Of course there is food available all over the city of Chicago for students to try. This is important because Saturday nights the dining halls are closed and it can be expensive to go out with friends for dinner. There is also a local supermarket if you want to cook for yourself.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Decent amount of places to eat off-campus, though not record-setting.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: It's amazing, ate there all 4 years. Very convenient, decent variety. Definitely one of the best in the country, and awarded as such. Very accommodating of allergies and so forth.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: there are some good options
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Great food in Chicago overall but somewhat limited options near Hyde Park.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review:
You can find decent food in dining halls but gets old quick.

Dining Hall meals cost about $10/meal, yes, even on the cheapest meal plan. (ripoff)

Off campus options are tasty but gets pricey to eat out regularly.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: It gets the job done
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are mostly Asian cuisine restaurants around campus, so not too much variety. But just a little bit further away there are more options, and they deliver.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: You can easily eat at all of the restaurants in the neighborhood in a year's time. Let's just say, no one goes to Hyde Park for it's food.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Abundant and with large variety. Much preferred over on-campus dining.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Expensive, low quality food. You must buy a plan to live in housing, artificially inflating the cost of housing as well.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Chicago has a host of different neighborhoods will all sorts of different types of restaurants, and at almost any one you can get an excellent meal with lots of food for less than $14 per person. In Hyde Park there are of course only so many options, but they're diverse, pretty good, and not expensive.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are a lot of options around campus, ranging from Starbucks and Einsteins to thai food, sushi, pizza, and fried chicken.  There are also food trucks that are great cheap options
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Medici's is a great little restaurant for Saturday nights when the dining hall is closed.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: You'll do this fairly often as dining halls are closed Saturday nights. Food is great, and if you don't want to spend, you can eat on campus at the local mini-restaurants we have.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: For most people dining is good but expensive. If you have a food allergy though it's a major pain. Despite being gluten-free getting off the meal plan was wayyy cheaper for me. And more filling.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: In addition to the diversity of off-campus restaurants (from Harold's fried chicken, burgers and pizza to Pad Thai, sushi, and chana masala), some of the restaurants package a bunch of meals that you can buy in on-campus coffee shops with Maroon Bucks.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There is unlimited dining for anyone that is on the meal plan.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are a lot of Italian and Chinese food places. Not much else.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are very limited food options in cafeteria.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: There are Kosher and Halal "stations" in each dining hall, as well as other stations such as "Euro" "Global" "Harvest (vegetarian)" "Deli" "Grill (burgers/chicken)" and a full salad/fruit bar. The Kosher station is the best by far, not sure why, but I go there pretty often. There is also Starbucks coffee, soda, juices, and tea in the dining hall. The quality is ok...sometimes it's pretty bad but sometimes it surprises me in a good way! I like that there's always salad and fruit options so I feel like I can eat healthily. Also the flex dollars (Maroon Dollars) can be used at the on-campus Subway, mini-marts, Einstein bagels, and various other cafes (lots of great coffee places!), which proves to be useful.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: We have two dining halls, they really are pretty good, but it is cafeteria food at that.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are many really good chains and local food places not very far from campus, they're all very good and not too expensive.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: All in all the dining options are good for a college.  Fourth meal was a great late night option.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: I haven't had campus food since my first year butt hey offer reasonable plans that incorporate cafeteria food with dining options that continue to expand.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Hyde Park has some pretty solid restaurants. If you want your quality of dining to increase, then there are 76 other neighborhoods in Chicago full of fine cuisine and different regional specialties!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review:
University of Chicago South Campus Dining Hall just failed its 4th health inspection this year. Nuff said.

University of Chicago: where food goes to die.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Theres some pretty good restaurants in Hyde Park and good variety. And theres the whole city of Chicago with restaurants!
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: It's a big city, so there are literally thousands of options, all within a few miles. In Hyde Park, there are plenty of options, including Mexican, Asian (including three Thai places in a row), and some great "American" options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: We easily get tired of the dining halls after a couple months, and the quality of food is variable. The price of the dining plan is outrageous for the food you get. Places you can use flex dollars at are usually good.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Speaking mostly from my experiences in the South Campus dining hall, the food is tasty, though repetitive, but really, it would be repetitive no matter where you went. The dining hall itself is absolutely gorgeous, with maroon carpets, a long table and chairs for each House, all wood, and beautiful chandeliers. It's very homey and cozy. :3
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There is some diversity, but many of the good options are pretty far away from campus. I often find myself going to a select few restaurants near campus unless I take a trip downtown or to Chinatown.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are three dinning halls on campus which are rather different from each other so students can choose which one fits them best. The food there is pretty good and one can choose from variety of different types of meals. An universal meal plan in required for all fresmen and sophomores who live in college housing which might be annoying for some people. Otherwise, there are many options for eating out or delivery, so many students opt out of their meal plan or choose to have less meals in order to enjoy the great restaurants and coffe shops on campus.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Some Places Are Great and Others Aren't – The dining hall I eat at, is awful. Unsanitary. The people aren't too nice either. However, down the road, is a place with chicken pot pie, giant waffles, and soft serve ice cream all day, every day. Here at Chicago, there can be some great food: a create your own stir fry, pasta bar, and a 4th meal with lots of delicious, fatty foods. There are certain places to be avoided but once you figure them out, the food here isn't too bad.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Food is good and good variety, but it's rather pricey.  Every dining hall is unique and provides a different experience.  Pierce is the best.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Amazing Options – Downtown Chicago is chock-full of dining options. Chicago is the 3rd biggest city in the world for a reason. The cultural/ethnic restaurants abound, and there are more than enough different dining choices to choose from. If you come to UChicago, make sure to go out into the city and explore!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Consistent, Nice Staff – The staff tries to be inventive with the food. Desserts are amazing (best cookies ever), and you know what to expect from the dinner. There are LOTS of veg and vegan options, and there's a kosher station.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Pretty Good If You Aren't Vegan – Lots of selection and options but if you are vegan you can kiss your nutrition goodbye
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Food Is Alright – There are many options for Kosher and vegetarians but sometimes there are days where there is nothing good to eat. They close kind of early and you're left hungry.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Excellent, but Inconsistent – Really does depend on your dining hall. The good ones, South and Pierce, have an incredible amount of selection at a very high quality.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: We have 3 dining halls on campus, and our meal plans are unlimited, which means you can swipe in as many times as you want and as much as you want. The food is really good for dining hall food.  I guess it can get kind of repetitive at times, but we have a Subway, Papa John's and other options for meals that can be bought with flex dollars, which are always great alternatives.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Great Dining – There are great dining options around Hyde Park and in the downtown area. The options for dining increase especially if you decide to go downtown
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Required Dining Sucks – The dining halls on campus are pretty good. Each has it's own specialty depending on how you're feeling, so it doesn't get boring after a while. The only problem is that unlimited meal plans are required your first year, which really, really sucks.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Food on Campus – The variety of options for dining on campus is great. In addition to the unlimited dining plan at the three dining halls, you are able to use flex dollars/maroon dollars at many of the coffee shops around campus. This year the school also added a Red Mango, Jamba Juice and an additional Subway!
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: There are a few good restaurants in the area, but not much fast food etc. that's super accessible. But the dining hall is pretty good and if you go downtown then the food is great so it's not really a problem.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: You can get anything around Hyde Park, and almost every restaurant has deals for students. Thai food's really popular around here, with 3 Thai restaurants along 55th street. Also check out Obama's favourite, Medici Bakery and Restaurant!
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Harold's Chichen is the best, but there's Wok 'N Roll, Thai 55, The Med, and The Big Easy Just opened up. There's also a Five-Guys that just opened up.  Honestly if you want good food just go into the city.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Good Food Although Not Many Options – With just three dining halls on campus, there is not much variety to choose from. The quality is generally good, but after a whole quarter of the same food, it can get boring.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Can't Opt Out! It's expensive, annoying, not open late at night and the staff can be rude.  But the worst thing is, you're forced to take a meal plan if you're a first year!  After that, I would definitely opt out.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Great Variety! The dining halls at UChicago have great variety and lots of different foods to choose from. In each of the three dining halls there is a pasta station, mexican station, asian station, sandwich station, pizza station, diner station, vegetarian station, kosher station, fresh salad bar, and of course my personal favorite, ice-cream and dessert station! I guarentee you won't go hungry on campus!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: The surrounding neighborhood has very few fast food places, which can be a bother sometimes when trying  to eat for cheap. All of the other places are reasonably priced but all too similar. There is very little variety.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Amazing, and Only Getting Better – I gave dining an A instead of an A+ only because the dining plan is expensive, and for the most part, you're forced to get an unlimited/close-to-unlimited plan (even with the new system). However, the food is awesome. Compared to many other schools I've visited, UChicago's food is the best. It can be a little repetitive at times, but the quality is always great. Our non-dining hall options are already pretty good, and growing as of this year. The administration is really putting in a lot of effort to make dining more varied and convenient for everyone.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Not Gourmet, but Good Enough – The dining hall I was in (Bartlett) had a variety of options that were healthy and relatively tasty.  Of course, eating the same eight meals for lunch and dinner year-round made it seem worse than it was, but in retrospect it was not bad at all. I was a vegetarian at the time, and I had no problems finding enough to eat healthily. The coffee shops around campus actually have really good lunch food options (shoutout to the Divinity School) and there are restaurants only a block from campus that serve pretty good thai/sushi/sandwiches/pastries/pizza/etc.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Go Downtown for Good Food – Not very good for the cost, especially compared to downtown options.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review:
Neighborhood Vs. the City – UChicago is located in Chicago's South Side neighborhood of Hyde Park. The food options in Hyde Park range from Harold's Chicken, providing the tastiness of fried chicken drenched in Harold's famous mild sauce, to ethnic hotspots such as Noodles and Thai 55, providing an Asian and Oriental splash to off campus dining options. While there are a number of off campus dining options in Hyde Park, the location of these restaurants with respect to campus is not always convenient. 
Also, UChicago's campus is only a bus and a "L" ride away from all the different restaurants and food hubs that the city of Chicago has to offer. If you're hunger can tolerate the commute, there's an endless amount of food options available to you.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review:
Dining Halls – Bartlett Dining hall-Good food sometimes, but mostly not.
Pierce Dining hall-Great breakfast food
South Campus Dining Hall-fresh veggies and fruits
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Several dining halls are shifting towards all you can eat but no food to go. Tons of different stations from kosher to grill to homestyle to asian stirfry to deli to pasta to pizza are at every meal. There are a lot of coffee shops in the area, a mini mart with snacks, and a common area with food stalls as well. Once you get off campus there a lot of amazing local restauraunts with some chains.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: Off Campus Eating – Hyde Park has plenty of options for off campus dining from extremely cheap to somewhat expensive. Medici's on 57th Street and Noodles Etc. are student favorites and are super close to campus. The UChicago student government also has a pretty sweet discount program at eight or so restaurants.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Not Terrible – The school definitely makes an effort to make campus dining good but you get tired of eating Bartlett and other dining halls quickly. Meat is always questionable. However the dining halls are conveniently located and the good hours make it a good place to grab food in between classes and such. The unlimited meal plan that all freshmen have is great.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: You've Got to Explore a Bit – Off campus dining really depends on how much time you're willing to invest. The nearby restaurants are great about student discounts and they're all really nearby. However, after a while Thai and pizza can get a little repetitive. If you wander into Chicago you've really got to wander. There are some absolutely awesome and affordable places and there are some totally mediocre ones. If you just go for the names you know and the places right on the Magnificent Mile then you're in for really expensive and hit-or-miss food. If you wander off the main areas, then it's a different story. As for specifics, if I gave you those it would ruin the fun :)
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: All You Can Eat – The food is alright, but the only options included are all you can eat, and sometimes you just want a snack between classes.  However, you can't do that unless you use flex dollars and they are limited and run out quickly
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There are a variety of locally owned ethnic foods. Some of my favorite are the Nile (Mediterranean) and Chant (Thai infusion). However, there are also some great more general places to go such as the infamous Medici, Z&H which has great salads and sandwiches, and the Sitdown with great pizza and, surprisingly, sushi. The one thing you will not find in abundance is chains.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: There aren't many accessible chain restaurants. The unique places are great like the Med and Edwardos, but the places you can go to quickly grab a bite to eat is very limited.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Dining Hall – Our dining halls rock, but they're expensive.  The quality is usually very high.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Hyde Park – Not very many major chains located nearby but in terms of cheap, quick food, the area is great, with everything from pizza to thai. Also everything is pretty vegetarian/vegan friendly.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Food Is Above Average. We have three dining halls and they are all relatively awesome! The menu changes everyday and the buffet style all you can eat system adds on to the diverse variety of food you can get. There are not that many restaurants near our school but the few there are such as Noodles etc and Medici are pretty decent!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Same Every Day – I guess its ok for a college level cafeteria but dont expect anything amazing. The fod is usually not very good and its very repetitive.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Check Out Hyde Park – There are some great restaurants just off campus. Tend to be a little expensive, but once in a while worth the indulgence.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Good Food, Repetitive – the food at the dining halls is, on most days, extremely good. they have kosher, vegan and halal options. Sometimes a few meals are however below average. Meal plan is $$$,but worth it if you dont enjoy cooking. If you like cooking, don't take the meal plan after your first yr.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Anywhere you go, you will find something you will like! Unfortunately, you won't be able to eat too healthy unless you settle for Subway on a college budget.
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: Better Than Expected – Some complain, and it's not amazing, but I don't mind it
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Not a whole lot in Hyde Park other than restaurants. There are a lot of great ones though; Thai, Mexican, Indian, Cajun, pretty much anything
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The food is bearable but super fattening and not so tasty.
Food.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: College Housing has been a joy so far! The Housing system has proved to be really fun and has provided a lot of opportunities to meet people and make friends. The rooms in South Campus are a nice size, and are pretty modern. It is also easy to get to class, and the dorm is right next to the dining hall, which is awesome, especially in the winter!
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The housing system is beneficial in general
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The housing system fosters a sense of community and belonging that I don't think I would have found elsewhere, which was an invaluable support network both as a first year adjusting to living away from home and as an upperclassman struggling with courses and extracurriculars and work. There's a healthy mix of first years and upperclassmen of all years, which provides a wealth of experience with the university to younger house members.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The dorms were a great way to meet people that you might not have met through other activities. They provide a network of older and younger people that want to help you.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The dorms are nice and now all dorms are very close to classes and dining halls.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: House community can easily become the nexus of your social circle, most are pretty tight knit (though some notably more than others)
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Was perfect before North was/is being bult
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Campus Housing was great for me. But there is a large variety of housing styles on campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: We have a house system to foster community-building within the campus housing.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: I really love dorm life. I do wish we didn't have to pay exorbitant prices for our laundry facilities and printing, but that's just one thing. Overall, my dorm feels like home.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Pretty nice dorms (South campus).
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I was in South Campus and I recommend it for everybody. My room was huge, I had a great roommate, all my friends are from my dorm. It was a good experience. I really liked my resident heads as well, they really helped me adjust. South Campus has all kinds of people in it, so you probably will find someone you can be friends with.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: So much better than on-campus housing. Literally doesn't even compare.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The Housing system is great in its uniqueness and how much it encourages spirit and friendship. My RHs and RAs were both amazing resources and people. My complaints are only within the administrational aspect - first, it's way too expensive and you need to be enrolled in a meal plan (which are complete ripoffs and the food is subpar) to be living in the dorms. This is largely why I moved out. Secondly, they make getting out of your contract for whatever reason absurdly difficult. Overall, I loved my house and house culture but it was not worth the downsides that came with it.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I live on campus and am not planning on leaving campus for next year, so I don't know much.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The rooms are great, but I am not crazy about the social life.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review:
Living off campus is generally much cheaper than living on campus, but you have to do a lot more - find a place, maintain it yourself, cook for yourself, be an adult.  Availability is good, through both older students moving out and directly calling the landlords.  Mac Apartments is the dominant landlord, and they have a lot of nice places but are known to not respond very quickly to maintenance issues.  Some apartments have heating issues, which is a HUGE problem in the winter and is something you really need to check for when you're looking for a new place.  Blackstone Management has some prime real-estate right between campus and the 53rd Street shopping corridor (they dominate the 54th and Woodlawn corner); they are better about maintenance and have nice apartments, but they can be a bit strange.  

There are certain areas where the vast majority of apartment units are rented by students - immediately east and north of campus.  These areas are generally fairly safe, but if you go west of Drexel or south of 62nd, you will enter much more dangerous neighborhoods and lots of crime, which sometimes spills over into student areas.  Break-ins and muggings happen to students multiple times a year.  

Almost every apartment has the same basic layout - a long hallway with rooms off one side and a kitchen at the end.  Almost every building has three floors, two apartments per floor.  This makes off-campus housing kind of boring - if you've seen one apartment, you pretty much know what all of them look like.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: I lived in Pierce, which has sadly now been torn down but fostered a very tight-knit House community and had the best dining hall on campus.  The vast majority of on-campus students now live in Max, South, Burton-Judson, or Snell-Hitchcock, all fairly large and thriving dorms very close to campus.  Burton-Judson and Snell-Hitchcock are known for their crazy-smart kids and very strong, quirky culture, while Max and South are much newer and have nicer facilities, but less tradition.  There are a few small off-campus dorms that I don't have much experience with.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: You are guaranteed housing all four years and the social community in the house is great when you're an underclassman.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: A lot of options, close to campus or you can choose to be farther from campus, but have better access to buses/trains/groceries. Mostly 1st and 2nd year students stay in housing. There's also a huge supply of apartments in Hyde Park, although those aren't quite as good (although they are cheap).
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I've been to various apartments, and there are tons of lovely options for people with different budgets.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I've seen way better at state schools, as far as amenities and preferable housing floor plans (lots of doubles and even triples), but the way they pair houses and create groups of people to live together and form bonds is incredible. I've never found people I've felt more compatible with than in my house.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I live in Burton-Judson which is a medium-sized dorm with a very close house system. I find the house system very supportive and have made most of my close friends through my house. Being in a close house also provides relationships with upperclassmen that you may not know otherwise.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Its Chicago! Can't say much about it since I have not lived off campus. Though a few of my friends say to avoid the south side of UIC.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: For the Commons South/West/North area it has a shared floor restroom/showers so everyone on that floor uses it and sometimes it gets a little dirty...
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: The main leasing company MAC isn't great, but there are a ton of apartments off campus and, overall, it is cheaper than living in a dorm.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Living on campus is great. The university has a system called the 'house' system which basically places you in a group of people that you live with. Every house has a common area, called the house lounge, and other amenities like dorm libraries, study spaces, kitchens, and some even have movie theaters. The University is very lenient on underage drinking.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: It's all the magic of Harry Potter houses, and then some.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Actually, I stayed on-campus because the dorms are excellent. But spent one term off campus, it was fine.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: I prefer to live in an apartment
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Living on campus is a great experience simply because of the housing system.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: All dorms have their pros and cons, I would recommend Stony/Blackstone/I-House for more access to the city and if you want an apartment life instead of the dorm life, Max/South if you're into partying and more into dorm life
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Campus housing can be a bit costly, but with financial aid it is a good option. The communities formed there make the whole college experience better and the stress manageable. It becomes a second home.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There are plenty of options for off-campus housing and they are all reasonably close to campus. The closer you get, the more expensive. But even further away properties are nice.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Good luck trying to find something right next to campus.  If you do (I was lucky enough to), the apartments are often smaller and costs more to rent.  However, when it is raining, snowing, and below -20F, I am not complaining.  Apartments that are 10-20 minutes walking are often larger and cheaper, but are not as easily assessable during the day, such as when you have 1.5 hours in between classes.
