It is often cheaper to live off campus (costs me bout $1500 less a year) and you do not have to eat the worst dining hall food in the country.  Numerous times last year, the dining halls were shut down for weeks due to safety/health concerns and the food is below subpar.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Each dorm has its own feel and usually people with similar interests pick the same dorm.  For example, athletes often live in Max-P, while more "socially-awkward" students choose to live in Snell-Hitchcock or BJ.  Depending on which dorm you choose, the amenities vary.  South is apartment style, while Max has suites, and BJ has community bathrooms but is more pleasing to the eye.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The incredible availability, variety, and affordability of off-campus housing makes it incredibly popular.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The dorms range wildly as regards various qualities--some have massive singles (available to 1st years) and some have the smallest double you'll ever see; some are shining, sparkling new buildings with wonderful amenities, and some are centuries-old antiques with radiators that ooze brown filth. Some dorms are a 1-minute walk from nearly any class on campus, and some require a ~10 - 15 minute shuttle ride to get to class. So, you can choose your dorm based on your own preferences and priorities, and the system is pretty easy and fair. Almost no matter where you are, you'll have a great community and very relaxed policies.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I don't have an apartment, but it seems pretty easy to swing.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There's a really great housing system that really engages you in the dorm life and creates a family among your floormates. I've heard mixed reviews about people's experiences with their house, but I love mine. We do everything together and it's a really nice place to call home. Uchicago is great about not really being strict and affording you the freedoms of an adult as long as you stay safe, which is nice compared to my friend's at other schools who can't have people of the opposite sex come into their room or can't engage in certain activities without being afraid of being arrested. Uchicago allows you to have the college experience you want and allows you to feel safe about it.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There are apartments available, but all the cheap ones are further from campus/may be in a dangerous area
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There are off campus options for everyone who wants it, and those I know who are off campus enjoy it.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: All dorms are different, and dorm life can be fun.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I love the house system that we have here. The first and closest friends you will make here are through your house.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Almost every student moves off-campus by their fourth-year, but I don't know anything about it yet.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review:
Lots of reasonably priced apartments, generally two- or three-bedroom situations. You can wind up pretty far from campus without a car, though. MAC Property Management is also known for being unreliable with work orders and so on.

Subletting if you are on campus in summer can get you a good deal.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The housing at this school is very good. In the dorm that I live in, we are a little farther off campus, but we are as close as family
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I live in one bed room condo. It is not so expensive and very safe. It is located near Lake Michigan and park.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review:
There's one company that owns the vast majority of apartments in Hyde Park (MAC Apartments) and everyone complains about them, but to be honest have you ever heard of someone who likes their landlord? They aren't actually that bad, people just like complaining. Finding housing can be a bit of a pain, you just have to keep your eye out online and ask MAC to show you available units. I ended up getting one of the few apartments in Hyde Park that isn't owned by MAC, and I can't say my landlord is sunshine and rainbows, but it's not the biggest deal.

I've never heard of someone not finding an apartment in Hyde Park, so availability isn't really an issue. As far as convenience, your natural instinct is to try and get an apartment within a couple blocks of campus, but it really isn't a big deal to be further out as long as you're Northeast/East of Campus. They have 3 buses that travel around Hyde Park and drop off on or near campus, so you'll never be more than 3 or so blocks from a bus stop. 

Cost-wise, it will vary. If you want a studio or one bedroom it will probably be pricier, probably $700-$800. If you have multiple bedrooms it gets cheaper. I'm in a four bedroom and we pay $2100 ($525 ea), but that's probably on the slightly lower end. I'd say average is about $600/mo.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: farther from campus=nicer housing for same price
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Campus housing is really nice if you're in the right place. There are many dorms that are very far from everything, so as long as you don't put yourself there (in exile) then you'll be fine!
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: South Campus is new, clean, has everything, and is a step away from the dining hall. It's fantastic.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There are a lot of available apartments and you can usually get a pretty good deal. Hyde Park isn't very expensive to live in. The landlords are hit or miss- MAC Property is the big owner of lots of apartments and they are pretty horrible but if you manage to find a smaller or private company usually you will be pretty well-off. The safety depends on how close you live to campus. If you live nearby, you can utilize the campus police and the blue lights. But if you are farther away, a lot of those apartments get broken into if you leave the windows open.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Livable, relatively cheap, but lots of crummy apartments/landlords who scam deposits.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Some of the dorms can be quite small, but some students are lucky and get really big rooms. Basically there's just a lot of variation in room type and dorm style. I really love the house system.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: From what I have seen so far there are a lot of options in the Chicago area, but at the same time, you need to search for exactly what you are specifically looking for.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Honestly, each spot on campus is great mostly because of the fact that it has it's own little perks associated with that area. For example, the unity found in my dorm hall, the I-House, is because of the family-like activities we do in our own little courtyard.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: There are a ton of apartments in Hyde Park and you can pick a place based on whether you want to be closer to campus, transportation, grocery stores, etc. The main rental company in Hyde Park isn't the best but it's improving; living off campus is much cheaper and the apartments themselves are usually pretty nice.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I lived in Stony Island because I needed a kitchen for medical reasons. I was not expecting much since it was far from campus and had less common space than the more "social" dorms, but I loved it! People seem satisfied with the dorms as a whole. Facilities are usually working and if not repairmen come soon after they are requested. Your house becomes very close to one another and IMs/parties/study breaks help with that. I would give an A, but U of C A- for the high cost of the mediocre (required) meal plan.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Pretty good; Mac is a huge off-campus landlord and is not the greatest.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: As a freshman I really appreciated living in a dorm with upperclassmen.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Since I am a graduate student, the options for living on campus are limited but they are available and appealing. They are very close to campus which is great but that also makes them more expensive. I also prefer to live on my own and I wish there were more options for independent graduate students that were much cheaper. I don't need a lot of space. However they are good at helping students find affordable off campus housing that is within distance of the campus.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Housing is pretty good. Theres a lot of variety but some dorms are really far from campus to be living in first year. The House system is great and helps you make friends but branch out too and meet people in other places!
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: The classic ivy-covered Gothic dorms are Snell and Hitchcock, which are usually in the most demand. If you're looking for newer dorms close to dining halls, gyms, and/or libraries, South and Max Palevsky are the best options. Try and avoid dorms like Broadview--although there's a lot of singles, they're too far from campus and make the commute difficult in the cold winters.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Generally Good, Watch Out for Old Buildings – Personally, I live in the worst dorm: far-away from campus, bug problems, far from dining hall, etc. However, most of the dorms are close to/on top of dining halls and are well maintained. Older dorms tend to have more pest problems, newer ones are best. UChicago kids do actually have fun, and the social atmosphere is quieter, but not bad. Two huge gyms, 3 dining halls with fairly good food. It gets old quickly, but has much more variety and accommodates vegan, vegetarian, etc. needs better than many other schools. A good school and generally good living environment, hence the high cost of attendance.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: South Campus is the most wonderful building ever. All the rooms are carpeted, every house has a staircase, a kitchen, 4-person apartments, and elevators. It's bright and warm and cheery and happy.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Hyde Park is full of apartments, a decent bit are in slightly sketchy neighborhoods, however.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Its Not that Bad – Well, I live in MAC, Its pretty safe, I guess. My apartment is located south hyde park. We never had any break ins, just alot of krazy party's. Me and my roomies like to get drunk and dare each other to flash the overnight maintenance guy.LOL lots Of funn some of them are pretty Hot.FUN TimEZ.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review:
Unsafe, Kind of Expensive – While UChicago itself is an amazing institution, the surrounding areas are not very safe, unfortunately. I think 3 out of 10 students have either been robbed or had their apartments broken into (I get emails almost weekly warning of a new incident), so that is a factor to consider. Apartments run from $600-$800 per person, per month, on average. 

Dorm life is bearable, but that also depends on your personality. We have a housing system wherein students are divided into "houses" (much like in Harry Potter), and if you do not fit in with the house in which you are placed, you will have trouble making friends outside of it for at least the first few moths of school.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: House System Is Great – Housing is pretty good at UChicago. When you get put in a dorm (based on your 1-3 ranking of dorm choices) freshman year, you also get put in a house within that dorm (think Hogwarts). Houses have 1st through 4th years usually, so you'll get to know a broader assortment of people than you would otherwise. It also gives you a good base of people to make friends with and that you know. Also, it means having a house table at the dining halls, which is great because you always have a place to sit where you won't have to sit alone. Most 3rd years move off campus, but some stay in the dorms all 4 years.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Some New Dorms, Others Are Awful – If you happen to find yourself living in the new dorms of: Max Palevsky, South Campus, New Grad, or Stoney Island, you will find yourself in a very nice situation.  Older dorms with their own perks include Snell/Hitchcock, I-House and the far-away dorms of Broadview, Blackstone, Breckenridge, and Maclean.  If you find yourself in Pierce, expect a horrible year and potentially a payout by the school as the conditions are mortifying.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Unique Dorm Experience – Roughly 40% of students live in housing and all students are guaranteed on-campus housing for 4 years if they so choose.  The house system is unique but most upperclassmen choose to move off-campus.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: There are many good options available to students for off-campus housing.  There are great options within walking and/or biking distance from the campus, the cost is fairly reasonable and less that dorm housing, and parking is free is you are fortunate enough to have a car at school.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Very Available – Most 3rd and 4th years live off-campus (~75%). And by off-campus I mean literally across the street. This means that there are a lot of apartments available- its very easy to find anything from a studio to a 5 bedroom. Rent isn't bad at all, and is actually a little cheaper than the cost of on-campus housing, so that's a plus. U of C police department patrols area and there are lots of blue lights and such around, so safety isn't really an issue.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: A Student Community – Moving off-campus isn't something that everybody does, but everybody that does it really likes it. The school has a few websites that can direct you to different leasing agents - and one company does have a monopoly in the area - so you'll find that certain crossroads (54th and Woodlawn, 55th and Hyde Park, 57th and Kimbark) have lots of students living on them. This creates pretty safe communities, which are convenient and close to campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: availability of off campus housing depends on taste,money and basically where you look.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: maybe I am sort of bias because I have the good fortune of living in a new dorm.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Variety in Dorms – Depending on your choice of dorm, you could go with aesthetics in the gothic feel of BJ, social aspect of Pierce (and the amenity of an in house dining hall, though at the cost of small rooms), the spacious singles of south (and the freedom of being farther removed from campus), or the "typical" college dorm of Max P. All have their advantages/disadvantages, so decide which aspect you're really going for.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review:
Flexible Apartment Environment – AAA

Apartments in Hyde Park typically come in two types: huge and spacious but run-down or clean, modern, and trendy but small studio style. It is really a matter of personal preference. The huge apartments make for excellent social/party spaces, if you are into that, and the modern apartments offer a cleaner more sophisticated life for those seeking that. Pricing is about in line with what one would expect from an urban area, but luckily Chicago is significantly cheaper than cramped cities like New York or LA. Apartment arrangements are also incredibly flexible due to the sheer volume of students constantly moving in and out. If you only want to stay for a month or so, or if you need to find roommates to split the tab, that will not be a problem at all. Virtually everywhere is connected by University Transportation, or you can walk if you don't mind the Winter.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: One of the most unique aspects to UChicago, and one of my personal favorites, is our house system. Every dorm here is split into houses of about 50-100 students, depending on the size of the dorm. These houses share resident heads, resident assistants, and house lounges. They go on house trips together, (such as to a show, restaurant or baseball game) and each house has 2 tables assigned to them in the dining hall where students in that house are encouraged to sit. The house system is such a nice community and support system to have, especially your first few years here. All of my closest friends, and favorite memories on campus, have come from my house!
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Close, and Affordable – Hyde Park is a residential neighborhood in Chicago so it naturally has a lot of nice housing, and it is all basically right on campus.  Since UChicago is a tight knit community it's quite easy to find a place to stay that is near by and not too expensive.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Food is the one thing that's lacking at the University of Chicago.  Not many late-night options
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Apartments are pretty expensive, even for the older ones.  Most lack air-conditioning and are in need of renovation.  There are some cheap ones, you just have to watch out for them
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review:
Good Campus Living – If you live on campus you have to have a meal plan. Our dining food is from Aramark, and its very low quality and unhealthy.

Housing is great and there are a variety of options to suit everyone's preferences.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: House Pride! UChicago's housing system ensures a tight knit community. In addition to being placed in a dorm, you're placed in a house, a group of 50-100 students in your dorm. These are the people you'll hang out with all year, whether you spend the evening studying together, go downtown for dinner or a movie, or check out events on campus.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Max Palevsky – First, it should be acknowledged that Max P does in fact have hideous architecture with all the rooms being uniform as either a single or double suite. Luckily though, the rest of the building is an effort to combat these negative qualities: The location is close to campus which is further advantaged by an underground tunnel system that allows you to see others in neighboring Max P dorms without having to step outside. In the summer/fall it's air conditioned and the heat is plentiful in the winter. Excellent water pressure, very clean, and still relatively new.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Comfortable, Convenient Living – I lived in Max Palevsky, and it was a great, convenient location. Library, dining hall, and classes were all really close. The facility itself is less than 10 years old, and though a little ugly, is clean and comfortable. Having your own bathroom in your room is a huge plus.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: "The Student Ghetto" – The University of Chicago is in Hyde Park, a southern area of Chicago. The buildings are all old, many very beautiful. After living in the dorms for a year, many opt to live off-campus. Most of the apartments are old and need much work. They are, however, close to campus, near shuttle routes that can bring students to and from campus, and decently priced.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Leave Housing – Off campus housing is definitely a better deal than living in the dorms and eating on the meal plan.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Max East – I liked the private bathrooms, but the roommate matching was unsuccessful. I did not get along with any of the 3. Houses within the dorms are good for socializing, athletes were mostly roomed in the max dorms which were nice because they were close to the facilities and i was close to all my friends as i was on the soccer team
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Social Life – U of C really does have a place for every kind of person. The stereotypical anti-social atmosphere does not accurately describe our campus at all. There are parties for those that want them along with groups of people who love to just stay in and play video games. Sometimes on campus activities can get pretty repetitive but going downtown is just as accessible as any other place on campus.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Mac Monopoly – Off-Campus housing is dominated by Mac. From what I hear, they are awful. I was fortunate enough with housing to avoid them, but as far as apartments go, there is really no other choice.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Good Value – Lots of apartments close to campus, not the newest and nicest but they are a great value
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review:
Dorms at UChicago are pretty great.  I stayed in Max Palevsky, which is right by the dining halls, the main quad, and the gym.  My Resident Heads were really chill, and there are almost no rules when it comes to drinking in the dorms, which is very different from other universities with strict policies.  It's nice that the students are trusted to do their own thing.  

Max Palevsky is also one of the most social dorms.  Other social dorms are South Campus and Pierce.  South Campus is further away, however, and Pierce is old and doesn't have air-conditioning.  Then there are dorms like BJ and Snell-Hitchcock, which is where the weirder, more "UChicago" type people go.  They seem to love it there, but those dorms are older as well.  There are also some dorms like Blackstone, which is super far away and nobody knows anyone who actually lives there.  In my opinion, Max is definitely the best choice.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Some Dorms Are Better – While the two biggest dorms, Max Palevsky and South Campus, are spacious and clean, some of the smaller ones can be pretty cramped and dirty.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Expensive, but Worth It – Being in Chicago, one should know that apartments and off-campus housing will be expensive. In this case, it is especially true if one wishes to live north of campus, in the safer areas. However, the money paid for safety is absolutely worth the extra cost, and most of the apartments are well-kept.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: A Dorm for Every Personality – Firstly, the house system is outstanding, and is especially great for first-years by providing a small close-knit group of people.  Secondly, the dorms are as eclectic as the personalities at this school. You have historic, Gothic, Hogwarts-esque dorms like Snell-Hitchcock; the huge newfangled glass one, South Campus; the orange Lego brick in the middle of campus, Max Pavlevsky; and so on. Although the newest dorms have the nicest features, each older one has its own "character" (in both a good and bad sense). In general, each dorm has positives and negatives which balance each other out, as shown by by the fact that everyone is proud of their own dorm and house.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Apartments Are Fairly Reasonable – There are some really nice apartments very nearby to the main quad.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Well, a lot of students stay in housing because we have such awesome dorms. Almost all of the buildings are owned by one company which is annoying, but compared to what my friends in other places have to deal with, we're pretty lucky. Everyone I knew found a cheap apartment fast. They can be small, but there are also tons of well-located, large-ish ones too.
